Write a program that reads a string and a list of valid dictionary words, then determines if the string can be segmented into valid words from the dictionary.

Input

  1. A string s representing the word to be checked.

  2. An integer m representing the number of words in the dictionary.

  3. A list of m strings representing the dictionary words.

Output

  • Print true if the string can be segmented into valid dictionary words; otherwise, print false.

Constraints

1 <= m <= 1000 (Number of words in the dictionary)
1 <= s.length <= 100 (Length of the string)
Each dictionary word length is between 1 and 100.

In the scenic mountains of Himachal Pradesh, Aman is hiking and collecting data about the heights of various peaks. He has recorded the heights of the peaks in an array, but he wants to identify a "peak" in this array. A peak is defined as an element that is greater than or equal to its neighbors. In the case of the first or last element, it only needs to be greater than or equal to its single neighbor.

For example, given the array of heights:

[1, 3, 20, 4, 1, 2]

The peak element is 20, as it is greater than its neighbors 3 and 4.

Your Task

Write a program that finds a peak element in an array using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  2. An array of n integers representing the heights of the peaks.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing a peak element in the array.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)
1 <= arr[i] <= 10^5 (Values of the elements)

In the vibrant city of Pune, Aarav is analyzing the daily earnings of his newly opened cafe over a month. He has recorded the profit and loss amounts in an array, where positive values represent profit and negative values represent loss. Aarav wants to identify the contiguous subarray with the maximum sum to understand the best period for his cafe's performance.

For example, given the array of daily profits and losses:

[-2, 1, -3, 4, -1, 2, 1, -5, 4]

The contiguous subarray with the maximum sum is [4, -1, 2, 1], which sums up to 6.

Your Task

Write a program that finds the maximum sum of a contiguous subarray using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of days (elements in the array).

  2. An array of n integers representing the daily profits and losses.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the maximum sum of a contiguous subarray.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)
-10^5 <= arr[i] <= 10^5 (Values of the elements)

In the serene landscapes of Kerala, Aditi is organizing a study group with her classmates. They have two different sets of exam scores from two different subjects. Aditi wants to find the median of these scores to understand the performance distribution better. The scores are stored in two sorted arrays.

For example, consider the following two sorted arrays:

Array 1: [1, 3]
Array 2: [2]

The median of these arrays is 2, as it is the middle value when combined.

If both arrays are of even length, the median is the average of the two middle numbers. For instance:

Array 1: [1, 2]
Array 2: [3, 4]

The median here would be (2 + 3) / 2 = 2.5.

Your Task

Write a program that finds the median of two sorted arrays using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the first array.

  2. An array of n integers representing the first sorted array.

  3. An integer m, representing the number of elements in the second array.

  4. An array of m integers representing the second sorted array.

Output

  • Print a single float value representing the median of the two sorted arrays, rounded to two decimal places.

Constraints

1 <= n, m <= 1000 (Number of elements in each array)
1 <= arr[i] <= 10^5 (Values of the elements)

In the vibrant city of Mumbai, Priya is conducting a survey on customer preferences for a popular snack. She collects data in the form of an array where each element represents a snack type chosen by a customer. Priya is particularly interested in identifying which snack type is the "majority" snack—defined as the snack type that appears more than half of the time in the array.

For instance, in the array:

[1, 2, 3, 2, 2, 4, 2]

The number 2 is the majority element because it appears 4 times, which is more than half of the total elements (7).

Your Task

Write a program that finds the majority element in the array using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  2. An array of n integers representing the snack types.

Output

  • Print the majority element if it exists; otherwise, print "No Majority Element".

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)
1 <= arr[i] <= 1000 (Values of the elements)

In the vibrant city of Pune, Ramesh is working on a real estate project where he needs to calculate the maximum area of a rectangular plot that can be formed within a histogram. The histogram represents various plots of land, where each bar's height corresponds to the plot's height.

For example, consider the histogram represented by the heights:

[2, 1, 5, 6, 2, 3]

The largest rectangle can be formed with the height 5 and extends across 2 width (from the 3rd to the 4th bar), giving an area of 10.

Your Task

Write a program that finds the area of the largest rectangle that can be formed in the given histogram using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of bars in the histogram.

  2. An array of n integers representing the heights of the bars.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the area of the largest rectangle.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of bars in the histogram)
1 <= heights[i] <= 10^4 (Height of each bar)

In the bustling city of Hyderabad, a computer science student named Riya is working on a project that simulates Conway's Game of Life, a fascinating cellular automaton devised by the mathematician John Conway. The game consists of a grid of cells, where each cell can either be alive (1) or dead (0). The state of each cell changes based on the number of alive neighbors it has.

The rules of the game are as follows:

  1. Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbors dies (underpopulation).

  2. Any live cell with two or three live neighbors remains alive (survival).

  3. Any live cell with more than three live neighbors dies (overpopulation).

  4. Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbors becomes a live cell (reproduction).

For example, given the following initial state:

0 1 0
0 0 1
1 1 1

The next state will be:

0 0 0
1 0 1
0 1 1

Your task is to write a program that simulates one step of the Game of Life based on the given rules.

Your Task

Write a program that reads the dimensions of the grid and its current state, then computes the next state of the grid according to the rules of the Game of Life.

Input

  • An integer n, representing the number of rows in the grid.

  • An integer m, representing the number of columns in the grid.

  • An n x m matrix of integers (0s and 1s) representing the current state of the grid.

Output

  • Print the next state of the grid after applying the Game of Life rules.

Constraints

  • 1 <= n, m <= 100 (Dimensions of the grid)

  • Each cell in the grid is either 0 or 1.

You are given an array of unique integers, which is a permutation of integers from 1 to n. You are allowed to swap any two elements in the array at most k times to get the largest possible lexicographical order of the array. A lexicographical order means that the array should be arranged in descending order.

Your goal is to achieve the maximum order of the array by performing no more than k swaps. If fewer than k swaps are required to achieve the largest possible order, then stop early.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ k ≤ n

  • The array arr is a permutation of the integers from 1 to n (i.e., it contains all integers from 1 to n exactly once).

Function Description

Complete the function largestPermutation which should return an array representing the largest lexicographical permutation achievable within k swaps.

Function Signature

int[] largestPermutation(int k, int[] arr)

Parameters:

  • k: An integer representing the maximum number of swaps allowed.

  • arr: An array of integers representing the elements to be permuted.

Returns:

  • The function should return an array containing the largest lexicographical permutation achievable within k swaps.

Input Format

  • The first line contains two space-separated integers, n and k, where n is the length of the array arr, and k is the maximum number of swaps allowed.

  • The second line contains n distinct space-separated integers representing the array arr.

Output Format

  • Print the largest lexicographical permutation of the array achievable within k swaps.

Mark is planning to buy toys for his child and wants to maximize the number of toys he can buy within a fixed budget. Each toy has a price, and all prices are positive integers. Given a list of toy prices and a budget, find the maximum number of toys that Mark can buy without exceeding his budget. Note that each toy can only be purchased once.

Function Description

Complete the function maximumToys, which takes:

  • prices (an array of integers): The prices of n toys.

  • k (an integer): The budget available to Mark.

The function should return an integer representing the maximum number of toys that can be bought without exceeding the budget.

Note: It's possible that some toy prices exceed the budget.

Function Signature

int maximumToys(int[] prices, int k)

Parameters:

  • prices: An array of n positive integers representing the prices of toys.

  • k: An integer representing the budget Mark has.

Returns:

  • The function should return an integer representing the maximum number of toys that can be bought without exceeding the budget.

Input Format

  • The first line contains two space-separated integers, n (the number of toys) and k (the budget).

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, representing the prices of the toys.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 10^5 (Number of toys)

  • 1 ≤ prices[i] ≤ 10^9 (Price of each toy)

  • 1 ≤ k ≤ 10^9 (Budget)

Note: All prices are integers.

Output Format

  • Print a single integer representing the maximum number of toys that can be bought without exceeding the budget.

A group of friends is collecting money for a social cause in Pune. Each friend decides to contribute a certain amount. However, the total collection must meet a specific target, and there is a limit on how many contributions can be used to reach this target. The goal is to find all possible combinations of contributions that exactly match the target sum using a given maximum number of contributions.

The order of contributions does not matter, and each contribution can be used only once in any combination. Your task is to find all unique combinations that exactly match the target sum with no more than the allowed number of contributions.

For example, if the contributions are [2, 3, 5], the target is 8, and the maximum number of contributions allowed is 2, the valid combination is:

  • [3, 5]

Your Task

Write a program that finds all unique combinations of contributions that exactly match a target sum, using no more than a given number of contributions.

Steps to Follow

  1. Input:

    • Read an integer n, representing the number of contributions.

    • Read n integers, representing the contributions.

    • Read two integers:

      • target: the sum that the contributions should add up to.

      • maxContributions: the maximum number of contributions allowed in any combination.

  2. Output:

    • Print all unique combinations of contributions that match the target sum, one combination per line, or print None if no such combination exists.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 15 (Number of contributions)

  • Each contribution is between 1 and 100.

  • 1 <= target <= 1000

  • 1 <= maxContributions <= n

Rohan loves sweets, especially laddoos. But he also wants to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Each laddoo has a certain calorie count, and Rohan needs to burn off those calories by walking. The more laddoos he eats, the harder it is to maintain his fitness routine.

If Rohan eats a laddoo with c calories after already having eaten k laddoos, he will need to walk at least 2^k * c miles to burn off those calories.

Given a list of laddoo calorie counts, your task is to find the minimum number of miles Rohan has to walk to burn off all the calories. Note that Rohan can eat the laddoos in any order to minimize the total miles walked.

For example, if the laddoo calorie counts are [2, 5, 4], Rohan can minimize his walking by eating them in the order [5, 4, 2]. The miles he would need to walk would then be:

  • For 5 calories: 2^0 * 5 = 5 miles

  • For 4 calories: 2^1 * 4 = 8 miles

  • For 2 calories: 2^2 * 2 = 8 miles

The total minimum miles walked would be 5 + 8 + 8 = 21.

Function Description
Complete the function rohanSweetDilemma which returns a long representing the minimum miles necessary to burn off the calories.

Function Signature

long rohanSweetDilemma(int[] laddooCalories)

Parameters:

  • laddooCalories: An array of integers representing the calorie counts of each laddoo.

Returns:

  • The function should return a long, which is the minimum miles Rohan needs to walk.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer n, the number of laddoos.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, representing the calorie counts of the laddoos.

Constraints:

  • The array will contain at least 1 laddoo.

Ravi is preparing for a marathon, and he records the distances he runs each day during his training. Over several days, he runs different distances, which are represented as an array. To optimize his training schedule, Ravi wants to know the smallest difference in distance between any two training days.

Your task is to help Ravi find this minimum difference between any two recorded distances. Given an array of integers representing the distances run on different days, calculate the minimum absolute difference between the distances of any two days.

For example, if Ravi's distances array is [3, -7, 0], the absolute differences between all pairs of distances are:

  • |3 - (-7)| = 10

  • |3 - 0| = 3

  • |-7 - 0| = 7

The minimum absolute difference is 3.

Function Description
Complete the function findMinDistanceDifference which should return an integer representing the minimum absolute difference between any two elements in the array.

Function Signature

int findMinDistanceDifference(int[] dailyDistances)

Parameters:

  • dailyDistances: An array of integers representing the distances Ravi runs on different days.

Returns:

  • The function should return an integer, which is the smallest absolute difference between any two distances.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains a single integer n, the size of the array dailyDistances.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, representing the distances.

Constraints:

  • The array contains at least 2 elements.

  • The distances can be both negative and positive, as Ravi sometimes does warm-up runs in the reverse direction.

Scenario: Ravi tracks his runs for different marathons throughout the year, and sometimes takes long breaks. These breaks result in very different distances on different days. He needs your help to find the smallest difference to balance his training.

Rohan is training for a major sports tournament that involves several preliminary matches. Initially, Rohan's fortune balance is 0. In each match, Rohan can either choose to win or lose, which affects his fortune. Each match is represented by two integers, F[i] and P[i]:

  • F[i] is the amount of fortune associated with the match. If Rohan wins the match, his fortune balance will decrease by F[i]. If he loses, his fortune balance will increase by F[i].

  • P[i] represents the match's priority:

    • If P[i] = 1, the match is high-priority.

    • If P[i] = 0, the match is low-priority.

Rohan's goal is to maximize his fortune by losing as many matches as possible. However, he can only afford to lose a maximum of k high-priority matches. Given these constraints, calculate the maximum fortune Rohan can achieve after participating in all the matches.

Example
Suppose the matches are described as follows:

Match:        Fortune:   Priority:
1             6          1
2             3          1
3             4          0

If Rohan loses all the matches, his fortune balance will be 6 + 3 + 4 = 13. However, if he can only afford to lose 1 high-priority match (k = 1), he should choose to lose the match with the highest fortune and win the other, maximizing his final fortune balance.

Function Description
Complete the function maximizeFortune which returns an integer representing the maximum fortune balance achievable.

Function Signature

int maximizeFortune(int k, int[][] matches)

Parameters:

  • k: an integer representing the maximum number of high-priority matches Rohan can lose.

  • matches: a 2D array where each element is [F[i], P[i]] representing the fortune balance and priority of the match, respectively.

Returns:

  • The function should return an integer representing the maximum fortune Rohan can achieve.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains two space-separated integers, n (number of matches) and k (maximum number of high-priority matches Rohan can lose).

  • The following n lines contain two space-separated integers, F[i] (fortune balance) and P[i] (priority) of each match.

Rohan has an array of stick lengths and wants to create a triangle using exactly three of these sticks. He wants to ensure that the triangle formed has the maximum possible perimeter. However, the triangle must be non-degenerate, meaning the sum of the lengths of any two sides must be greater than the length of the third side.

If there are multiple valid triangles with the same maximum perimeter:

  1. Choose the one with the longest maximum side.

  2. If there is more than one such triangle, choose the one with the longest minimum side.

  3. If there is still a tie, print any one of the triangles.

If it is not possible to form any non-degenerate triangle, return -1.

Example
For stick lengths [1, 1, 1, 3, 3], the possible triangles are [1, 1, 1] and [1, 3, 3]. The triangle [1, 3, 3] has a larger perimeter, so the sides of the triangle should be printed as 1 3 3.

Function Description
Complete the function maximumPerimeterTriangle which returns an array of integers representing the side lengths of the chosen triangle in non-decreasing order or -1 if no non-degenerate triangle can be formed.

Function Signature

int[] maximumPerimeterTriangle(int[] sticks)

Parameters:

  • sticks: an array of integers representing the lengths of the available sticks.

Returns:

  • An array of three integers representing the sides of the chosen triangle in non-decreasing order, or an array containing -1 if no non-degenerate triangle can be formed.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer n, the number of sticks.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, representing the lengths of the sticks.

Ravi has a grid of characters, with each character being a lowercase letter from 'a' to 'z'. He wants to rearrange the elements of each row in alphabetical order (ascending) and then check if all the columns of the grid are in ascending alphabetical order from top to bottom. If both conditions are satisfied, return "YES". Otherwise, return "NO".

Function Description
Complete the function gridRaviChallenge which returns a string "YES" or "NO" based on the conditions specified.

Function Signature

String gridRaviChallenge(String[] grid)

Parameters:

  • grid: An array of strings representing the grid of characters.

Returns:

  • The function should return a string "YES" if both row-wise and column-wise alphabetical order is satisfied, and "NO" otherwise.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer t, the number of test cases.

  • Each test case contains:

    • An integer n, the number of rows (and columns) in the grid.

    • n strings, each of length n, representing the rows of the grid.

Constraints:

  • Each string consists of lowercase letters only.

Ravi has two lists of integers, A and B, both containing n elements. He wants to maximize the number of matching pairs between A and B. A pair (i, i) is considered a "matching pair" if A[i] == B[i]. However, Ravi is allowed to change exactly one element in B to any value of his choice to maximize the number of matching pairs.

Your task is to help Ravi find the maximum possible number of matching pairs he can achieve by making one optimal change in B.

For example:

A: [3, 5, 7, 9]
B: [3, 5, 9, 9]

Initially, the number of matching pairs is 3. By changing B[2] from 9 to 7, Ravi can increase the number of matching pairs to 4.

Function Description
Complete the function maximizePairwiseMatches which returns an integer representing the maximum number of matching pairs Ravi can achieve after making one optimal change in B.

Function Signature

int maximizePairwiseMatches(int[] A, int[] B)

Parameters:

  • A: An array of integers representing the first list.

  • B: An array of integers representing the second list.

Returns:

  • The function should return an integer representing the maximum number of matching pairs Ravi can achieve after making one optimal change in B.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains a single integer n, the number of elements in A and B.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers representing the elements of A.

  • The third line contains n space-separated integers representing the elements of B.

Constraints:

  • You must change exactly one element in B.

Ravi is a school teacher who needs to distribute candies to his students based on their performance ratings. Each student has a rating score, and they all sit in a line. Ravi needs to ensure:

  1. Every student receives at least one candy.

  2. If two students are sitting next to each other, the student with a higher rating must receive more candies than the other.

Help Ravi find the minimum number of candies he needs to distribute to make sure all the rules are followed.

Function Description
Complete the function distributeCandies which returns an integer representing the minimum number of candies Ravi must buy.

Function Signature

int distributeCandies(int n, int[] ratings)

Parameters:

  • n: An integer representing the number of students.

  • ratings: An array of integers representing the ratings of each student.

Returns:

  • The function should return an integer representing the minimum number of candies required.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains a single integer n, the number of students.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, each representing the rating of a student.

Constraints:

  • There is at least one student, and the ratings are all positive integers.

Example
Example Input:

3
1 2 2

Example Output:

4

Explanation:

  • The optimal way to distribute the candies is [1, 2, 1], ensuring that the second student receives more candies than the first (due to a higher rating), and the third student receives 1 candy as their rating is not higher than the second.

Ravi is investigating a case where he needs to generate a special type of number called a "Decent Number." A Decent Number is a number made up of only the digits 3 and 5, with the following rules:

  1. The count of 5s in the number must be divisible by 3.

  2. The count of 3s in the number must be divisible by 5.

  3. The number must be as large as possible given its length n (i.e., it should be the largest possible lexicographical order).

You need to help Ravi by printing the largest Decent Number for a given length n. If it's not possible to form a Decent Number for a given n, print -1.

Constraints:

  • The number of digits n can be any positive integer.

Function Description:
Complete the function decentNumber which should print the largest Decent Number with n digits, or -1 if such a number cannot be formed.

Function Signature:

void decentNumber(int n)

Parameters:

  • n: An integer representing the number of digits in the Decent Number.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer t, the number of test cases.

  • The next t lines each contain an integer n, representing the number of digits for each test case.

Output Format:

  • For each test case, print the largest possible Decent Number for n digits, or -1 if no such number can be formed.

Note to Students: Your task is to implement the decentNumber function to print the largest possible Decent Number for each given n, or -1 if no such number is possible.

In a small village near Varanasi, there is a clever rat named Chintu. Chintu lives in a maze-like house with various pathways, some of which are blocked. One day, Chintu wants to find a way from the start of the maze to the destination while avoiding blocked paths. The maze is represented as a grid of size n x m, where 0 indicates a blocked cell and 1 indicates an open cell.

Chintu can only move right or down at any point in time. The task is to find all possible paths from the top-left corner of the maze ([0,0]) to the bottom-right corner ([n-1, m-1]), while avoiding obstacles.

Example for Better Understanding

Imagine the maze is represented as follows:

1 0 1
1 1 0
0 1 1

Here:

  • 1 indicates a cell that Chintu can traverse.

  • 0 indicates a blocked cell (obstacle).

The possible paths Chintu can take from the top-left corner to the bottom-right corner are:

  1. Right → Down → Down → Right

  2. Down → Down → Right → Right

So, there are 2 possible paths for Chintu to reach the destination safely.

Your Task

Write a program that finds all possible paths for Chintu to go from the start of the maze to the destination, avoiding obstacles. Print each path as a sequence of directions: "R" for moving right and "D" for moving down.

Steps to Follow

  1. Input:

    • First, read two integers, n and m, representing the dimensions of the maze.

    • Then, read the n x m grid containing 0s and 1s.

  2. Output:

    • Print all possible paths from the start to the destination. Each path should be printed as a sequence of "R" and "D".

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n, m <= 10 (Dimensions of the maze)

  • The maze always has 1 at the start ([0, 0]) and the destination ([n-1, m-1]).

Sanjay, an enthusiastic mathematician from Kolkata, enjoys solving number puzzles. One of his favorite activities is finding combinations of numbers that sum up to a particular target value. Given a list of positive integers, Sanjay wants to find all unique combinations of exactly k numbers that sum up to a specified target.

The combination of numbers must use each number at most once and should not contain duplicate combinations (combinations with the same numbers but in different order are considered the same).

For example, if the numbers are [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], and the target is 6 with k = 2, some of the valid combinations are:

  • [1, 5]

  • [2, 4]

Your task is to help Sanjay by writing a program that finds all unique combinations of exactly k numbers from a list that sum up to the target value.

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose Sanjay has the numbers [2, 3, 6, 7], a target sum of 7, and k = 2. The possible valid combinations are:

  • [3, 4]: These two numbers add up to the target 7 and use exactly 2 numbers.

However, if k = 3 and the target is still 7, there would be no valid combinations because there are no 3 numbers in the list that sum up to 7.

Your Task

Write a program that finds all unique combinations of exactly k numbers from the given list that sum up to a given target.

Steps to Follow

  1. Input:

    • Read an integer n, the size of the list of numbers.

    • Read n integers, representing the list of numbers.

    • Read two more integers:

      • k: the number of elements each combination should have.

      • target: the sum that each combination should add up to.

  2. Output:

    • Print all unique combinations of exactly k numbers from the list that sum up to target. Each combination should be printed on a new line as space-separated values.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 15 (Number of elements in the list)

  • 1 <= k <= n (Number of elements in each combination)

  • 1 <= target <= 100 (Target sum)

  • All elements in the list are positive integers between 1 and 50.

A Knight in chess moves in an "L" shape: it can jump to a position that is two squares in one direction and one square in a perpendicular direction. For example, from a position (x, y), a knight can move to (x+2, y+1), (x+2, y-1), (x-2, y+1), (x-2, y-1), (x+1, y+2), (x-1, y+2), (x+1, y-2), or (x-1, y-2).

Your task is to find all possible paths that a knight can take to visit every cell of an n x m chessboard exactly once, starting from a given position.

For example, given a 3 x 3 chessboard, and starting from the top-left corner (0,0), one possible path is for the knight to visit all cells exactly once without revisiting any cell.

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose the chessboard is 3 x 3, and the knight starts at position (0,0). The knight can move in "L" shapes to explore the board. The goal is to find all possible sequences of moves that cover every cell on the board exactly once.

Your Task

Write a program that finds and prints all valid paths for the knight to cover every cell of the chessboard exactly once, starting from a specified position.

Steps to Follow

  1. Input:

    • Read two integers n and m, representing the dimensions of the chessboard.

    • Read two more integers startX and startY, representing the starting position of the knight.

  2. Output:

    • Print all valid paths as sequences of positions in the order they are visited by the knight. Each path should be printed as a space-separated sequence of coordinates (x, y).

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n, m <= 5 (Dimensions of the chessboard)

  • 0 <= startX < n and 0 <= startY < m (Valid starting position)

In a word search puzzle, you're given a grid of letters and a word to search for in that grid. The word can be constructed from adjacent cells (up, down, left, right, and diagonally). The same letter cell can only be used once in constructing the word.

For example, in the grid:

A B C E
S F C S
A D E E

If the word to search for is "ABCCED", you can trace a path through the grid to find it.

Write a program that checks if a given word exists in the grid of letters. Return true if the word exists, otherwise false.

  1. Input:

    • Read two integers n and m, representing the dimensions of the grid.

    • Read n strings of length m each, representing the grid of letters.

    • Read a string word representing the word to be searched for.

  2. Output:

    • Print true if the word can be found in the grid, otherwise print false.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n, m <= 6 (Dimensions of the grid)

  • All characters in the grid and word are uppercase English letters (A-Z).

  • The length of the word is between 1 and 36.

In a city in Maharashtra, a software engineer named Rohan has a grid representing a map of the city. Each cell in the grid contains a positive integer that represents the cost of traveling through that cell. Rohan wants to find the minimum cost to travel from the top-left corner of the grid to the bottom-right corner. He can only move down or right at any point in time.

For example, consider the following grid:

1 3 1
1 5 1
4 2 1

The path with the minimum cost would be:

  • Start at (0,0) with cost 1

  • Move to (0,1) with cost 3

  • Move to (1,1) with cost 5

  • Move to (1,2) with cost 1

  • Move to (2,2) with cost 1

The total cost for this path is 1 + 3 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 7.

Your task is to write a program that calculates the minimum cost to reach the bottom-right corner from the top-left corner of the grid.

Your Task

Write a program that reads a grid of integers and calculates the minimum path sum from the top-left corner to the bottom-right corner.

Input

  1. An integer m, representing the number of rows in the grid.

  2. An integer n, representing the number of columns in the grid.

  3. A grid of size m x n where each cell contains a positive integer.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the minimum cost to reach the bottom-right corner.

Constraints

1 <= m, n <= 100 (Dimensions of the grid)
1 <= grid[i][j] <= 1000 (Cost of each cell)

Ananya is learning about string manipulation and wants to develop a text editor that can calculate how similar two strings are. She learned that one way to measure the difference between two strings is by calculating the Edit Distance. The Edit Distance is defined as the minimum number of operations required to convert one string into another. The allowed operations are:

  1. Insertion: Insert a character into the string.

  2. Deletion: Delete a character from the string.

  3. Substitution: Replace one character in the string with another.

For example, to convert the string "kitten" to "sitting", the minimum number of operations required is 3:

  • Substitute 'k' with 's' → "sitten"

  • Substitute 'e' with 'i' → "sittin"

  • Insert 'g' at the end → "sitting"

Your task is to write a program that calculates the Edit Distance between two given strings.

Your Task

Write a program that reads two strings and calculates the Edit Distance between them.

Input

  1. A string str1.

  2. A string str2.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the Edit Distance between the two strings.

Constraints

1 <= str1.length, str2.length <= 100 (Length of the strings)
All characters in the strings are lowercase English letters (a-z).

Neha is fascinated by palindromes and is working on a project that involves string manipulation. She wants to find the longest palindromic subsequence in a given string. A palindromic subsequence is a sequence that appears in the same order forward and backward but does not need to be contiguous.

For example, in the string "character", the longest palindromic subsequence is "cec" or "carac" with a length of 5.

Your task is to write a program that calculates the length of the longest palindromic subsequence in a given string.

Example for Better Understanding

Given the string "bbabcbcab", the longest palindromic subsequence is "babcbab" or "bcabcb" with a length of 7.

Your Task

Write a program that reads a string and calculates the length of the longest palindromic subsequence.

Input

  1. A string s representing the string to be analyzed.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the length of the longest palindromic subsequence.

Constraints

1 <= s.length <= 1000 (Length of the string)
All characters in the string are lowercase English letters (a-z).

In a bustling city in India, a software engineer named Ankit has designed a robot that can move through a grid. The grid consists of 0s (representing open paths) and 1s (representing obstacles). Ankit's robot can only move down or right at any point. Given a grid, he wants to find out how many unique paths the robot can take to reach the bottom-right corner from the top-left corner while avoiding the obstacles.

For example, consider the following grid:

0 0 0
0 1 0
0 0 0

The robot can take the following unique paths to reach the bottom-right corner:

  • Path 1: (0,0) → (0,1) → (0,2) → (1,2) → (2,2)

  • Path 2: (0,0) → (1,0) → (2,0) → (2,1) → (2,2)

Thus, the output for this grid would be 2.

Your Task

Write a program that reads a grid containing obstacles and calculates the number of unique paths the robot can take to reach the bottom-right corner.

Input

  1. An integer m, representing the number of rows in the grid.

  2. An integer n, representing the number of columns in the grid.

  3. A grid of size m x n where each cell contains either 0 (path) or 1 (obstacle).

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the number of unique paths to reach the bottom-right corner.

Constraints

1 <= m, n <= 100 (Dimensions of the grid)
0 <= grid[i][j] <= 1 (0 for path, 1 for obstacle)

In a small village in India, Ramesh is analyzing the production of crops for the upcoming season. He wants to know the maximum product of a contiguous subarray of crop yields over a given period. The yields can be both positive and negative, and Ramesh wants to maximize the product of the yields in any subarray.

For example, given the array of crop yields:

[2, 3, -2, 4]

The maximum product of a contiguous subarray is 6, which comes from the subarray [2, 3].

Your Task

Write a program that calculates the maximum product of a contiguous subarray within a given array of integers.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  2. An array of n integers, where each integer can be positive or negative.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the maximum product of a contiguous subarray.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)
-100 <= arr[i] <= 100 (Values of the elements)

In the beautiful city of Udaipur, Nisha is developing a software application for a landscape design company. The company needs to determine the outer boundary (convex hull) of a set of points representing the corners of a potential garden layout. The convex hull is the smallest convex polygon that encloses all the given points.

For example, given the following points:

(0, 0), (1, 1), (2, 2), (2, 0), (1, 0), (0, 1)

The convex hull would be the polygon formed by the points:

(0, 0), (2, 0), (2, 2), (0, 1)

Your Task

Write a program that computes the convex hull of a set of 2D points using the Divide and Conquer approach. The output should include the vertices of the convex hull in counter-clockwise order.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of points.

  2. A list of n points, each represented as a pair of integers (x, y).

Output

  • Print the vertices of the convex hull in counter-clockwise order. Each vertex should be printed in the format (x, y).

Constraints

3 <= n <= 1000 (Number of points)
-10^4 <= x, y <= 10^4 (Coordinates of the points)

In a bustling startup in Gurgaon, Riya is working on a financial analysis application that aims to optimize investment strategies. She needs to identify all unique quadruplets from a list of integers that add up to a specific target sum. This problem is known as the Four Sum Problem.

For example, consider the array:

[1, 0, -1, 0, -2, 2]

If the target sum is 0, the unique quadruplets that meet this condition are:

[(-2, 0, 0, 2), (-1, 0, 0, 1), (-1, -1, 0, 2)]

Your Task

Write a program that finds all unique quadruplets in the array that sum up to the given target value using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  2. An array of n integers representing the input values.

  3. An integer target, representing the target sum.

Output

  • Print all unique quadruplets that sum up to the target value. Each quadruplet should be printed in ascending order.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 200 (Number of elements in the array)
-10^9 <= arr[i] <= 10^9 (Values of the elements)
-10^9 <= target <= 10^9 (Target value)

In the tech-savvy city of Hyderabad, Priya is developing a search engine for her university project. She needs to efficiently search for a given pattern in a long text using the Knuth-Morris-Pratt (KMP) algorithm. The KMP algorithm is a classic example of the Divide and Conquer approach in string matching, allowing her to perform searches efficiently without backtracking.

For example, given the text:

ABABDABACDABABCABAB

And the pattern:

ABABCABAB

The pattern appears at index 10.

Your Task

Write a program that implements the KMP algorithm to find all occurrences of a pattern in a given text. Return the starting indices of all matches.

Input

  1. A string text representing the long text in which to search.

  2. A string pattern representing the pattern to search for.

Output

  • Print the starting indices of all occurrences of the pattern in the text. If there are no matches, print -1.

Constraints

1 <= text.length, pattern.length <= 1000
All characters in the text and pattern are uppercase English letters (A-Z).

In the vibrant city of Jaipur, Meera is tasked with designing the layout for a new art gallery floor. The gallery has a rectangular floor of size n x m, and she wants to tile it using 1 x 2 domino tiles. However, she has some constraints: she can either place the tiles vertically or horizontally, but she cannot leave any gaps.

For example, consider a gallery floor of size 2 x 3:

XXO
XXO

Where X represents the tiles used and O represents empty spaces. Meera can tile this area in several ways.

Your Task

Write a program that calculates the total number of ways to completely tile the n x m gallery floor using 1 x 2 domino tiles with the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. Two integers n and m, representing the dimensions of the floor.

Output

  • Print the total number of ways to tile the n x m floor.

Constraints

1 <= n, m <= 30 (Dimensions of the floor)

In the serene village of Mahabaleshwar, Aditi is organizing a treasure hunt for the children in her community. She hides treasures (represented as integer values) in different locations, each location corresponding to an index in an array. Aditi wants to know the maximum value of the treasures hidden in these locations, and she decides to implement a solution using the Divide and Conquer approach.

For example, given the following array of treasures:

[4, 1, 7, 3, 9, 2]

The maximum treasure value is 9, which is found at index 4.

Write a program that finds the maximum value in an array using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  • An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  • A list of n integers representing the values of the treasures.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the maximum treasure value found in the array.

Constraints

  • 1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)

  • -10^4 <= arr[i] <= 10^4 (Values of the elements)

During a family function in Mumbai, all the young cousins are trying to decide how to group themselves. Each cousin can either form a group with other cousins or stay alone. Given n cousins labeled from 1 to n, find all the possible sequences in which the cousins can be grouped together. Each grouping is represented as a combination of numbers.

For example, if there are 2 cousins, labeled as 1 and 2, the possible ways to group them are:

  1. [1] [2]: Both cousins stay alone.

  2. [1, 2]: Both cousins form a single group.

    Write a recursive program to generate and print all possible groupings of the cousins labeled 1 to n.

Suppose there are 3 cousins labeled 1, 2, and 3. The possible ways to group them are:

  1. All cousins stay alone: [1] [2] [3]

  2. Cousin 1 forms a group with cousin 2, and cousin 3 stays alone: [1, 2] [3]

  3. Cousin 1 forms a group with cousin 3, and cousin 2 stays alone: [1, 3] [2]

  4. Cousin 2 forms a group with cousin 3, and cousin 1 stays alone: [2, 3] [1]

  5. All cousins form a single group: [1, 2, 3]

Therefore, for 3 cousins, there are 5 possible groupings.

Steps to Follow:

  1. Input:

    • Read a single integer n, representing the number of cousins.

  2. Output:

    • Print all possible groupings of the cousins from 1 to n.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 4 (Number of cousins)

Ramesh lives in a small town in Maharashtra where he owns multiple houses lined up in a row. Each house has a certain value of gold that Ramesh can collect. However, there’s a catch: Ramesh cannot collect gold from two adjacent houses as it would raise suspicion among his neighbors. To maximize his gold collection, Ramesh wants to know the maximum sum of gold he can collect from non-adjacent houses.

Your task is to write a program that calculates the maximum sum of gold Ramesh can collect without taking gold from two consecutive houses.

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose the value of gold in the houses is as follows:

  • House 1: 3

  • House 2: 2

  • House 3: 7

  • House 4: 10

The possible ways Ramesh can collect gold are:

  1. Take gold from House 1 and House 3: Sum = 3 + 7 = 10

  2. Take gold from House 1 and House 4: Sum = 3 + 10 = 13

The maximum sum is 13.

Your Task

Write a program that reads the number of houses and their respective gold values, then calculates and prints the maximum sum of gold Ramesh can collect without taking gold from two consecutive houses.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of houses.

  2. A list of n integers, representing the value of gold in each house.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the maximum sum of gold Ramesh can collect.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 100 (Number of houses)
0 <= gold[i] <= 10^4 (Value of gold in each house)

In the vibrant city of Pune, Rahul is organizing a community event and has been given two sorted arrays representing the RSVPs of attendees. He needs to merge these two sorted arrays into a single sorted array while maintaining the order. This task will help him create an organized list of all attendees.

For example, if Rahul has the following two arrays of RSVPs:

Array 1: [1, 3, 5]
Array 2: [2, 4, 6]

The merged array should be: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6].

Your Task

Write a program that merges two sorted arrays into one sorted array using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the first array.

  2. An array of n integers, which is sorted in non-decreasing order.

  3. An integer m, representing the number of elements in the second array.

  4. An array of m integers, which is also sorted in non-decreasing order.

Output

  • Print the merged sorted array.

Constraints

1 <= n, m <= 1000 (Number of elements in each array)
The elements of both arrays are within the range of integers.

In the busy streets of Bangalore, Ravi is analyzing the prices of fruits in different markets. He wants to find the k-th smallest price among the fruit prices he collected from various vendors. Ravi needs your help to efficiently find this price using the Divide and Conquer approach.

For example, given the array of fruit prices:

[7, 10, 4, 3, 20, 15]

If Ravi wants to find the 3rd smallest price, the result should be 7.

Your Task

Write a program that finds the k-th smallest element in an unsorted array of integers.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  2. An array of n integers representing the prices.

  3. An integer k, representing which smallest element to find.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the k-th smallest element in the array.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)
1 <= k <= n (Valid range for k)

In the heart of Delhi, Neha is studying the performance of various software applications. She has a list of scores representing the performance of applications sorted by the score. However, she needs to know how many times the applications' scores are out of order, which she refers to as "inversions." An inversion is a condition where a larger score appears before a smaller score in the array.

For example, consider the array of scores:

[3, 1, 2]

The inversions in this array are:

  • (3, 1)

  • (3, 2)

Thus, there are a total of 2 inversions.

Your Task

Write a program that counts the number of inversions in an array using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of elements in the array.

  2. An array of n integers representing the scores.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the number of inversions in the array.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of elements in the array)
-10^5 <= arr[i] <= 10^5 (Values of the elements)

In the picturesque hills of Uttarakhand, Aisha is conducting a survey to find the closest pair of trees in a forest, represented by their coordinates on a 2D plane. Given the coordinates of multiple trees, Aisha needs to determine the smallest distance between any two trees. This will help her in planning the layout of a new nature trail.

For example, consider the following points representing tree coordinates:

(1, 2), (3, 4), (5, 1), (2, 3)

The closest pair of points here is (1, 2) and (2, 3), with a distance of approximately 1.41.

Your Task

Write a program that calculates the smallest distance between any two points using the Divide and Conquer approach.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of points.

  2. An array of n pairs of integers representing the coordinates of the points.

Output

  • Print a single float value representing the smallest distance between any two points, rounded to two decimal places.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of points)
-1000 <= x[i], y[i] <= 1000 (Coordinates of the points)

Raju loves going for morning walks, and near his house, there is a long staircase that he likes to climb. The staircase has n steps, and Raju can take either 1 step or 2 steps at a time.

For example, if there are 3 steps, Raju can climb them in the following ways:

  • 1 step + 1 step + 1 step (3 steps of 1 each)

  • 1 step + 2 steps (1 step followed by 2 steps)

  • 2 steps + 1 step (2 steps followed by 1 step)

Your task is to write a program that calculates the number of distinct ways Raju can climb to the top of the staircase.

Example for Better Understanding:

If the staircase has n = 4 steps, the possible ways Raju can climb are:

  • 1 step + 1 step + 1 step + 1 step (4 steps of 1 each)

  • 1 step + 1 step + 2 steps (2 steps after 2 single steps)

  • 1 step + 2 steps + 1 step (A pair of steps in between single steps)

  • 2 steps + 1 step + 1 step (2 steps followed by 2 single steps)

  • 2 steps + 2 steps (2 pairs of steps)

Therefore, there are 5 ways to climb a staircase of 4 steps.

Your Task

Write a program that reads an integer n representing the number of steps in the staircase and calculates the total number of distinct ways Raju can climb to the top.

Input

  • A single integer n representing the number of steps in the staircase.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the number of distinct ways Raju can climb to the top of the staircase.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 45

Rani runs a shop where she frequently needs to make change for her customers. Given a target amount of money, Rani wants to give her customers the exact amount using the fewest possible coins. You are provided with a list of available coin denominations and a target amount.

Your task is to write a program that finds the minimum number of coins required to make the exact target amount. If it's not possible to make the exact change, print -1.

Example for Better Understanding:

If the coin denominations are [1, 2, 5] and the target amount is 11, the possible combinations to reach 11 are:

  • 5 + 5 + 1 (3 coins)

  • 5 + 2 + 2 + 2 (4 coins)

  • 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 1 (6 coins)

Therefore, the minimum number of coins required to make 11 is 3.

Your Task

Write a program that reads a list of coin denominations and a target amount. The program should calculate and print the minimum number of coins required to make the target amount.

Input

  1. An integer m, representing the number of coin denominations.

  2. A list of m integers representing the coin denominations.

  3. An integer target, representing the amount of money to make with the fewest coins.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the minimum number of coins required to make the target amount. If it's not possible to make the exact change, print -1.

Constraints

  • 1 <= m <= 100 (Number of coin denominations)

  • 1 <= target <= 10,000 (Target amount)

  • All coin denominations are positive integers and less than or equal to target.

Madhav is working on a new project involving analyzing sales data for a supermarket in Bengaluru. He has a list of the sales amount for n consecutive days. Now, he wants to find out the maximum sales amount that can be collected by considering any contiguous subarray of these sales days.

Your task is to write a program that calculates the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray from the given list of daily sales amounts.

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose the sales amounts for 7 consecutive days are:

  • Sales: [-2, 1, -3, 4, -1, 2, 1, -5, 4]

To find the maximum sum of a contiguous subarray, the possible subarrays and their sums are:

  • [4, -1, 2, 1]: Sum = 6

  • [1, -3, 4, -1, 2, 1]: Sum = 4

  • [-2, 1]: Sum = -1

The maximum sum of any contiguous subarray is 6.

Your Task

Write a program that reads an array of sales amounts and calculates the maximum sum that can be obtained from any contiguous subarray.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of days.

  2. An array of n integers, representing the sales amount on each day.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 1000 (Number of days)
-10^4 <= sales[i] <= 10^4 (Sales amount on each day)

Gopal loves mountain climbing, and he's currently training on a staircase in his local village in Uttarakhand. The staircase has n steps, and Gopal can decide how many steps to climb at a time. Unlike the typical 1 or 2 steps option, Gopal has a list of step sizes that he can use. He wants to know the total number of distinct ways to reach the top of the staircase using the allowed step sizes.

For example, if the allowed step sizes are [1, 3] and there are 4 steps in total, Gopal can reach the top in the following ways:

  • 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 (taking all 1-steps)

  • 1 + 3 (taking one 1-step and one 3-step)

  • 3 + 1 (taking one 3-step and one 1-step)

Therefore, the total number of ways to reach the top is 3.

Your Task

Write a program that calculates the number of distinct ways Gopal can climb to the top of the staircase given the total number of steps and a list of possible step sizes he can take.

Input

  1. An integer n, representing the number of steps in the staircase.

  2. An integer m, representing the number of different step sizes.

  3. A list of m integers, representing the possible step sizes Gopal can use.

Output

  • Print a single integer representing the number of distinct ways Gopal can reach the top of the staircase.

Constraints

1 <= n <= 50 (Total number of steps)
1 <= m <= 10 (Number of possible step sizes)
1 <= step size[i] <= n (Valid step sizes)

Priya is organizing her wedding in Bangalore. In her family, there's a tradition that each guest can bring additional guests. For instance, a direct guest can bring 2 more guests, and each of those guests can bring more. Priya needs to calculate the total number of guests who will be attending her wedding, including both the direct guests and all the additional guests they may bring.

Let’s break this down with an example so that it's easier to understand:

Imagine Priya is inviting 3 direct guests. These guests are allowed to bring some additional guests as follows:

  • The first guest can bring 1 additional guest.

  • The second guest brings 0 additional guests (they come alone).

  • The third guest can bring 2 additional guests.

Calculating Total Guests:

  1. Direct Guests: Priya has invited 3 people directly.

  2. Additional Guests:

    • The first guest brings 1 additional guest. So now, we have 3 (direct) + 1 = 4 guests.

    • The second guest brings 0 guests. The count remains 4.

    • The third guest brings 2 additional guests. So, 4 + 2 = 6 guests in total.

So, the total count of guests attending the wedding will be 6.

Your Task:
Write a program that calculates the total number of guests attending the wedding. Include both the direct guests and all the additional guests they bring.

Steps to Follow:

  1. Input:

    • First, read an integer n, representing the number of direct guests Priya is inviting.

    • Then, read n integers, where each integer specifies the number of additional guests a direct guest can bring.

      • For example, if n = 3 and the array is [1, 0, 2], this means:

        • The first guest brings 1 additional guest.

        • The second guest brings 0 guests.

        • The third guest brings 2 additional guests.

  2. Output:

    • Print the total number of guests attending the wedding, which is the sum of the direct guests and all additional guests brought by them.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 100 (Number of direct guests)

  • 0 <= additionalGuests[i] <= 10 (Each direct guest can bring up to 10 additional guests)

  • The total number of guests (including additional guests) will not exceed 1000.

Let’s walk through a detailed example step-by-step to understand how to calculate the total number of guests.

Input:

3 1 0 2

  1. Reading Input:

    • The first number 3 indicates that Priya has 3 direct guests.

    • The next 3 numbers are 1, 0, 2, representing how many additional guests each direct guest can bring:

      • The first guest brings 1 more guest.

      • The second guest brings 0 guests.

      • The third guest brings 2 more guests.

  2. Calculating the Total Number of Guests:

    • We start with the count of 3 direct guests (n = 3).

    • Now, we add up the number of additional guests each direct guest brings:

      • First guest: 1 additional guest. So, totalGuests = 3 + 1 = 4.

      • Second guest: 0 additional guests. The count remains totalGuests = 4.

      • Third guest: 2 additional guests. Now, totalGuests = 4 + 2 = 6.

    Therefore, the total number of guests, including both direct and additional guests, is 6.

Output:

6

Rahul is an adventurous trekker exploring the Himalayan mountains. Every step he takes can either be an ascend (going up by 1 unit height) or a descend (going down by 1 unit height). Rahul wants to know the total number of ways he can complete his trek, given a certain number of steps he can take.

For example, if he has 2 steps to take, the possible ways are:

  • 1 ascend and 1 descend: This brings him back to the original height.

  • 2 ascends: He climbs up by 2 units.

  • 2 descends: He goes down by 2 units.

Your task is to help Rahul find all possible sequences of taking these steps.

Your Task:
Write a recursive program that takes the number of steps Rahul can make and prints all possible sequences of those steps, where each step can be either an "A" (ascend) or a "D" (descend).

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose Rahul can take 3 steps. Let’s go through the possible sequences:

  • AAA: 3 ascends, Rahul ends up 3 units above his starting height.

  • AAD: 2 ascends followed by 1 descend, ending up 1 unit above the starting height.

  • ADA: Ascend, descend, and ascend, ending up 1 unit above.

  • ADD: Ascend and 2 descends, ending up 1 unit below the starting height.

  • DAA: Descend followed by 2 ascends, ending up 1 unit above.

  • DAD: Descend, ascend, and descend, returning to the original height.

  • DDA: 2 descends and an ascend, ending up 1 unit below.

  • DDD: 3 descends, ending up 3 units below the starting height.

So, for 3 steps, there are 8 possible sequences.

Steps to Follow:

  1. Input:

    • Read a single integer n, representing the number of steps Rahul can take.

  2. Output:

    • Print all possible sequences of n steps using "A" for ascend and "D" for descend.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 10 (Number of steps Rahul can take)

Sita is on a vacation in Goa and loves collecting seashells of different colors. She wants to collect a target number of seashells for each color she likes. She has a sequence in which she picks shells, where each shell can either be of color Red or Blue.

Your task is to help Sita find all possible sequences of length n that show how she can collect the seashells. Each sequence consists of the characters "R" (representing a Red shell) and "B" (representing a Blue shell).

For example:
If Sita plans to pick 2 shells, the possible sequences would be:

  • RR: She picks 2 Red shells.

  • RB: She picks 1 Red and 1 Blue shell.

  • BR: She picks 1 Blue and 1 Red shell.

  • BB: She picks 2 Blue shells.

Your Task:
Write a recursive function to print all possible sequences of length n using the characters "R" and "B".

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose Sita plans to pick 3 shells. Let’s break down all possible sequences:

  • RRR: 3 Red shells.

  • RRB: 2 Red shells followed by 1 Blue shell.

  • RBR: 1 Red, 1 Blue, and 1 Red shell.

  • RBB: 1 Red shell followed by 2 Blue shells.

  • BRR: 1 Blue and 2 Red shells.

  • BRB: 1 Blue, 1 Red, and 1 Blue shell.

  • BBR: 2 Blue shells followed by 1 Red shell.

  • BBB: 3 Blue shells.

So, for 3 shells, there are 8 possible sequences.

Steps to Follow:

  1. Input:

    • Read a single integer n, representing the number of shells Sita wants to collect.

  2. Output:

    • Print all possible sequences of length n using "R" for Red and "B" for Blue.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 10 (Number of shells to be collected)

During the Diwali festival, Rajesh decorates his house with a string of lights. Each light in the string can either be ON (represented by "1") or OFF (represented by "0"). Rajesh wants to know all possible ways to arrange the lights on the string. He has a string of n lights, and each light can be in one of the two states (either ON or OFF).

Your task is to write a program that prints all possible arrangements (combinations of "1"s and "0"s) for the n lights.

Example for Better Understanding

Suppose Rajesh has 3 lights. Each light can be either ON ("1") or OFF ("0"). Let’s look at all the possible ways to arrange these lights:

  • 111: All lights are ON.

  • 110: The first two lights are ON, and the third is OFF.

  • 101: The first and third lights are ON, and the second is OFF.

  • 100: The first light is ON, and the remaining two are OFF.

  • 011: The first light is OFF, and the last two are ON.

  • 010: The first and third lights are OFF, and the second is ON.

  • 001: The first two lights are OFF, and the third is ON.

  • 000: All lights are OFF.

Therefore, for 3 lights, there are 8 possible arrangements.

Your Task:
Write a recursive function to print all possible combinations of the n lights, where each light can be either "1" (ON) or "0" (OFF).

Steps to Follow:

  1. Input:

    • Read a single integer n, representing the number of lights in the string.

  2. Output:

    • Print all possible combinations of n lights, using "1" for ON and "0" for OFF.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 10 (Number of lights in the string)

WITH RECURSIVE employee_hierarchy AS (
    SELECT employee_id, manager_id, 1 AS level
    FROM employees
    WHERE manager_id IS NULL
    UNION ALL
    SELECT e.employee_id, e.manager_id, eh.level + 1
    FROM employees e
    INNER JOIN employee_hierarchy eh ON e.manager_id = eh.employee_id
)
SELECT employee_id, level FROM employee_hierarchy;

WITH RECURSIVE numbers AS (
    SELECT 1 AS num
    UNION ALL
    SELECT num + 1
    FROM numbers
    WHERE num < 5
)
SELECT SUM(num) AS total FROM numbers;

Explanation:
Views with aggregate functions are non-updatable because aggregates do not directly map to individual rows in the base table.
SELECT DISTINCT department FROM employees WHERE salary > 50000;
SELECT COALESCE(NULL, 'SQL', NULL, 'Query');

Consider the following scenario in a SQL database:

  • Transaction T1 locks Row A and requests Row B.

  • Transaction T2 locks Row B and requests Row A.

Aarav has an array of integers. He wants to find all unique combinations of three numbers (triplets) from this array that add up to 0.

Each triplet must follow these rules:

  • All three numbers must be at different indices (i, j, k).

  • The same triplet should not be repeated in the final result (e.g., [-1, 0, 1] and [0, -1, 1] are the same and should be counted only once).

  • The order of triplets or the order of numbers inside the triplets does not matter.

Your task is to help Aarav write a function that returns all such unique triplets that sum to 0.

Hint :

  • First, sort the array. This helps in skipping duplicate values easily.

  • Fix one number (nums[i]) and then use two pointers (left and right) to search for the other two numbers.

  • Move the pointers:

    • If the sum is less than 0 → move the left pointer forward to increase the total.

    • If the sum is more than 0 → move the right pointer backward to decrease the total.

    • If the sum is exactly 0 → store the triplet and skip any duplicates.

Rahul has a sorted array, but someone rotated it a few times. Now the array looks broken, but all the numbers are still there, just shifted. He wants to find the smallest number in the array.

You need to help him write a Python function that returns the minimum element in the rotated sorted array.

Here’s what rotated means:
If the original array is [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7] and it is rotated 4 times, it becomes [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2].
Even though it's broken in the middle, it's still sorted in both parts.

Your job is to find the smallest number.
You must solve it using binary search, which runs in O(log n) time.

You are given a number n. Your task is to find out how many zeroes are at the end of the number n! (n factorial).

What is factorial?
Factorial of n means:
n! = n × (n - 1) × (n - 2) × ... × 2 × 1

For example:

  • 5! = 120 → It ends in 1 trailing zero

  • 10! = 3628800 → It ends in 2 trailing zeroes

So, you don't need to calculate the full factorial — just count how many zeroes are at the end.

Why Do Trailing Zeroes Appear?

  • A trailing zero is formed by multiplying 10.

  • And 10 = 2 × 5

  • But in factorials, there are always more 2s than 5s.

  • So we only need to count how many times 5 is a factor in the numbers from 1 to n.

That’s the trick

Ayaan is given a sorted array of integers, but it may have been rotated at some unknown point. The array contains unique numbers in ascending order, but after rotation, it looks broken.

He also has a number called target. His goal is to find the index of this target number in the array.

If the target is present, return its index.
If not, return -1.

You have to help Ayaan write a Python function that solves this problem using binary search. Your solution must run in O(log n) time.

Example to Understand Rotation:
Original sorted array: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7]
After rotating at index 3 → [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2]
You can see the array is still sorted in parts.

Your task: Given a rotated array and a target value, return the index where the target exists.

Kiran is practicing arrays, and she comes across a tricky problem. She is given an array of integers. These integers can be positive, negative, or even zero.

She wants to find a subarray (a part of the array with continuous elements) such that when she multiplies all the numbers in that subarray, the result is the highest possible product.

You have to help her write a Python function that returns the maximum product she can get by multiplying numbers from any one subarray.

Example to Understand:
If the array is [2, 3, -2, 4], then the subarray [2, 3] gives a product of 6, which is the maximum among all possible subarrays.

If the array is [-2, 0, -1], then the answer is 0. Even though multiplying -2 * -1 gives 2, they are not next to each other — so they are not part of the same subarray.

Your solution must work efficiently, even for long arrays. You are not allowed to use nested loops or brute force.

Note:

  • Subarrays must be continuous (no skipping).

  • Some numbers in the array can be negative or zero.

  • The product result will always fit in a 32-bit integer.

You are given a sentence as a string s. This sentence might have:

  • Extra spaces at the beginning or end

  • Multiple spaces between words

Your task is to:

  1. Reverse the order of the words in the sentence.

  2. Clean up all the spaces:

    • Remove extra spaces from the beginning and end

    • Use only one space between words

Return the final cleaned sentence as a string.

Think of it like this, You’re just flipping the sentence, word by word, and making sure there are no messy spaces left.

Hint:

  • Use .split() to break the sentence into words (this removes all extra spaces automatically).

  • Use Python's list slicing to reverse the list.

  • Join the words back using ' '.join() with a single space.

Sahil has an array of integers. Some numbers are positive, and some are negative. He wants to find a part of the array (called a subarray) where the sum of the numbers is the highest possible.

Your task is to write a Python function that returns the maximum sum of any subarray.

A subarray means a continuous part of the array. You cannot skip elements in between.

Anjali has an array of integers called nums. She wants to create a new array called answer such that each element at index i in answer is the product of all elements in nums except nums[i].

Your task is to help Anjali return this new array.
You are not allowed to use the division operator.
Your solution must run in O(n) time.

Note:

  • The product of elements before and after the current index must be calculated using loops.

  • The final product of each index must fit in a 32-bit integer.

Ankita is solving a puzzle where she has a list of numbers and a target value. Her task is to pick two different numbers from the list such that their sum equals the target. She should then return the indices of those two numbers.

For example, if the list is [2, 7, 11, 15] and the target is 9, then 2 + 7 = 9, and their indices are [0, 1]. Help Ankita write a Python function to find and return such indices.

Note:

  • Only one such valid pair exists in the list.

  • The same element cannot be used twice.

  • Return the indices in any order.

Rohit has an array of integers called nums. He wants to rotate the elements of the array to the right by k steps.

That means:

  • Every element in the array moves to the right by k places.

  • Elements that move past the end come back around to the start.

You need to help Rohit modify the array in-place (without using extra space for another array).

Hint:

  • To rotate by k steps:

    • Take the last k elements and bring them to the front.

    • Shift the first n - k elements to the back.

  • But to do it in-place, we use the reverse method:

    1. Reverse the entire array.

    2. Reverse the first k elements.

    3. Reverse the remaining n - k elements.

Rohit is learning how to add numbers in binary format.
He is given two strings a and b, where each string represents a binary number (i.e., made up of only '0' and '1' characters).

Your task is to help Rohit add the two binary numbers, and return the sum as a new binary string.

Notes:

  • You must return the answer as a binary string, not an integer.

  • Input strings may be of different lengths.

  • No leading zeros in input (except when the value is "0").

Hint:

  1. Start adding from the last digit of both strings.

  2. Use a carry variable to keep track of overflow.

  3. Use a loop to go from right to left and build the result.

  4. Don’t forget to reverse the final result string at the end!

Ishaan is given two integer arrays — nums1 and nums2, and a positive integer k.

A pair (i, j) is called good if:
nums1[i] is divisible by nums2[j] * k

Your task is to help Ishaan count the total number of good pairs across both arrays.

Hint:
Loop through all combinations of nums1[i] and nums2[j], and check.

Aarav is exploring bitwise operations and has been given an array called nums of length n.
He needs to create a new array called answer with length n - 1.

Each element in answer is calculated using the bitwise OR (|) of adjacent elements in nums.
In simple words:

  • answer[i] = nums[i] | nums[i + 1]

Help Aarav write a Python function that returns the final answer array.

Hint:
Use a loop from 0 to n-2 and apply the | operator on each nums[i] and nums[i+1].

Sana is playing with a list of numbers and wants to check if it's "special."
An array is called special if every pair of adjacent elements has different parity.

This means:

  • One number must be even

  • The other must be odd
    (in every pair)

Your task is to help Sana write a Python function that returns True if the array is special, and False otherwise.

Hint:
Use the modulus operator % 2 to check parity.
Compare nums[i] % 2 with nums[i+1] % 2 for each pair.

You are given two lists of strings: word1 and word2.
Each list represents a string — formed by joining all elements in order.

Your task is to return True if both lists represent the same final string, and False otherwise.

Notes:

  • You must compare the actual combined strings, not individual elements.

  • Strings are case-sensitive.

  • You can assume all elements in both lists are valid lowercase strings.

Hint:

  • Join the strings in each array using "".join(word1) and "".join(word2).

  • Then compare the two final strings.

Example 1:

Input: word1 = ["ab", "c"], word2 = ["a", "bc"]

Output: true

Explanation:

word1 represents string "ab" + "c" -> "abc"

word2 represents string "a" + "bc" -> "abc"

The strings are the same, so return true.

You are given a list of distinct 2-letter lowercase strings called words.
Your task is to find the maximum number of pairs you can form such that:

  • Each pair (i, j) satisfies i < j

  • words[i] == reverse(words[j])

Each word can be used in at most one pair.
Return the total number of such valid pairs.

Notes:

  • Strings are exactly 2 characters long.

  • All words are distinct.

  • A word and its reverse must appear in the list for them to form a pair.

  • Each string can appear in only one pair.

Hint:

  • Store words in a set while looping.

  • For every word, check if its reverse exists in the set.

  • If found, count the pair and remove both from the set.

You are given an array of lowercase strings called words.

Your task is to return a list of all characters that are common across all strings, including duplicates.

That means:

  • If a character appears more than once in every word, include it that many times in the result.

  • If a character does not appear in every word, do not include it.

The final result must be returned in ascending (alphabetical) order.

Note:

  • All words consist of only lowercase English letters.

  • Duplicates do matter — e.g., if 'l' appears twice in every word, include it twice in the result.

  • The output should be sorted alphabetically.

Hint:

  • Use Python’s collections.Counter to count character frequency in each word.

  • Start with the count from the first word, then update it by intersecting (&) with the others.

  • Build the final result based on the minimum count found for each character.

  • Don’t forget to sort the final list before returning.

Priya is helping her grandmother plant flowers in a long flowerbed.
Some plots already have flowers, and some are empty. The rule is: You cannot plant flowers in two adjacent plots.

That means if a plot has a flower, its immediate left and right neighbors must be empty.

You're given:

  • A list called flowerbed, where:

    • 1 means a flower is already planted

    • 0 means the plot is empty

  • A number n — the number of new flowers Priya wants to plant

You need to write a function that returns True if she can plant all n flowers without breaking the rule. Otherwise, return False.

Note:

  • Priya can only plant in plots that are 0

  • She cannot plant in a 0 if either neighbor is 1

  • The flowerbed might start or end with 1 or more zeros

Hint:

  • Loop through the flowerbed

  • For each empty plot (i.e., 0), check its neighbors:

    • If left and right are also 0 (or out of bounds), plant one

    • Mark the current spot as 1 and reduce n

Aryan is working with a list of numbers and wants to find the third highest unique number.

He is given an integer list called nums. His job is to return the third distinct maximum number in the list.

But here’s the twist:

  • If there are less than 3 unique numbers, Aryan should return the biggest number in the list instead.

What You Need to Do:

  1. Remove duplicates from the list

  2. Sort the remaining numbers in descending order

  3. If 3 or more unique numbers are present, return the 3rd biggest

  4. If not, return the biggest number

Hint:

  • You can use a set() to remove duplicate numbers

  • Use sorted(..., reverse=True) to sort from biggest to smallest

  • Then just pick the third one (index 2), if it exists

Example:

For input:
[1, 2, 2, 5, 3, 5]

  • After removing duplicates → [1, 2, 3, 5]

  • Sorted descending → [5, 3, 2, 1]

  • Third max = 2

Output: 2

Ritika is learning about binary numbers. Her task is to count how many set bits (1s) are present in the binary form of a given positive integer n.

These set bits are also known as the Hamming Weight of the number.

Your goal is to help Ritika write a Python function that takes a number n as input and returns the number of 1s in its binary representation.

What is a Set Bit?

A set bit is a bit in the binary representation of a number that is equal to 1.

For example:

  • 5 in binary is 101, which has 2 set bits

  • 8 in binary is 1000, which has 1 set bit

Task:

Write a function that takes a number n and returns how many set bits (1s) are there in its binary representation.

Ravi is given two strings, s and t.

He wants to check if s is a subsequence of t.
A subsequence means:
You can remove some characters (or none) from t without changing the order of the remaining characters to get s.

For example:

  • "abc" is a subsequence of "ahbgdc" ✅

  • But "axc" is not a subsequence of "ahbgdc" ❌

Help Ravi write a function that returns True if s is a subsequence of t, else False.

Hint:

  • Use two pointers: one for s and one for t.

  • Move through both strings:

    • If characters match, move the s pointer forward.

    • Always move the t pointer forward.

  • If you reach the end of s, then all its characters were found in order — return True.

Neha has an array of integers. She wants to check if any number repeats in the array.
Your task is to help her write a Python function that returns True if any number appears more than once, otherwise return False.

Note:

  • Return True if there is at least one duplicate.

  • Return False if all elements are unique.

Aanya is checking phrases to see if they are palindromes — words or phrases that read the same forwards and backwards.

But there’s a twist:

  • She must ignore all spaces, punctuation, and special characters.

  • She must also ignore letter case (treat uppercase and lowercase as the same).

Your job is to help her write a function that returns True if the cleaned version of the string is a palindrome, and False otherwise.

Hint:

  • First, remove all non-alphanumeric characters using .isalnum().

  • Convert all letters to lowercase using .lower().

  • After cleaning, check if the string is the same when reversed.

Sneha is working with a group of words (strings), and she wants to find something common among all of them.

Her task is to find the longest common prefix shared by all the strings in the list.
If there’s no common starting part, she should return an empty string "".

Help Sneha write a function that does this.

Hint:

  • First, pick the first word as your base.
