In the vibrant city of Bengaluru, a festival is being organized where colorful balloons are taped onto a flat wall representing the XY-plane. Each balloon is represented as an interval on the x-axis. The organizers need to minimize the number of arrows required to pop all the balloons. An arrow can be shot vertically from any point along the x-axis and will burst all balloons that intersect with its path.

Given an array of intervals points where points[i] = [starti, endi] represents a balloon whose horizontal diameter stretches between starti and endi, determine the minimum number of arrows that must be shot to burst all balloons.

For example:

  • If points is [[10,16],[2,8],[1,6],[7,12]], the output should be 2 because two arrows can burst all the balloons: one arrow at x = 6 and another at x = 11.

  • If points is [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6],[7,8]], the output should be 4 because each balloon needs a separate arrow.

Function Description: Complete the function findMinArrowShots with the following parameter:

int findMinArrowShots(int[][] points)

Returns:

This function returns the minimum number of arrows required to burst all the balloons.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= points.length <= 105

  • points[i].length == 2

  • -2^31 <= xstart < xend <= 2^31 - 1

Ravi and Priya are playing a detective game. Ravi has written a ransom note, and Priya has a magazine. Ravi wants to know if he can construct his ransom note using the letters from Priya's magazine. Each letter in the magazine can only be used once in the ransom note.

Given two strings ransomNote and magazine, return true if ransomNote can be constructed by using the letters from magazine and false otherwise.

Function Description: Complete the function canConstruct which should determine if the ransom note can be constructed from the magazine.

Function Signature:

boolean canConstruct(String ransomNote, String magazine)

Parameters:

  • ransomNote: A string representing the ransom note.

  • magazine: A string representing the magazine.

Returns: A boolean value indicating whether the ransom note can be constructed from the magazine.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains the string ransomNote.

  • The second line contains the string magazine.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= ransomNote.length, magazine.length <= 10^5

  • ransomNote and magazine consist of lowercase English letters.

Ravi and Priya are playing a word game. They have two strings, s and t, and they need to determine if the strings are isomorphic. Two strings are isomorphic if the characters in s can be replaced to get t. All occurrences of a character must be replaced with another character while preserving the order of characters. No two characters may map to the same character, but a character may map to itself.

Given two strings s and t, return true if s and t are isomorphic, and false otherwise.

Function Description: Complete the function isIsomorphic which should determine if the two strings are isomorphic.

Function Signature:

boolean isIsomorphic(String s, String t)

Parameters:

  • s: A string representing the first word.

  • t: A string representing the second word.

Returns: A boolean value indicating whether the two strings are isomorphic.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains the string s.

  • The second line contains the string t.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length, t.length <= 5 * 10^4

  • s and t consist of any valid ASCII character.

Ravi and Priya are playing a word game. They have a pattern string pattern and a string s, and they need to determine if s follows the same pattern. A string s follows a pattern if there is a bijection between a letter in pattern and a non-empty word in s. This means each letter in pattern maps to exactly one unique word in s, and each unique word in s maps to exactly one letter in pattern.

Given a pattern and a string s, return true if s follows the same pattern, and false otherwise.

Function Description: Complete the function wordPattern which should determine if the string s follows the pattern.

Function Signature:

boolean wordPattern(String pattern, String s)

Parameters:

  • pattern: A string representing the pattern.

  • s: A string representing the sequence of words.

Returns: A boolean value indicating whether the string s follows the pattern.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains the string pattern.

  • The second line contains the string s.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= pattern.length <= 300

  • pattern contains only lowercase English letters.

  • 1 <= s.length <= 3000

  • s contains only lowercase English letters and spaces.

  • s does not contain any leading or trailing spaces.

  • All the words in s are separated by a single space.

Ravi and Priya are playing a word game. They have two strings, s and t, and they need to determine if t is an anagram of s. An anagram is a word or phrase formed by rearranging the letters of a different word or phrase, typically using all the original letters exactly once.

Given two strings s and t, return true if t is an anagram of s, and false otherwise.

Function Description: Complete the function isAnagram which should determine if t is an anagram of s.

Function Signature:

boolean isAnagram(String s, String t)

Parameters:

  • s: A string representing the first word.

  • t: A string representing the second word.

Returns: A boolean value indicating whether t is an anagram of s.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains the string s.

  • The second line contains the string t.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length, t.length <= 5 * 10^4

  • s and t consist of lowercase English letters.

Ravi and Priya are organizing a word game event. They have a list of words and want to group the words that are anagrams of each other. An anagram is a word formed by rearranging the letters of another word, using all the original letters exactly once.

Given an array of strings strs, group the anagrams together. You can return the answer in any order.

Function Description: Complete the function groupAnagrams which should group the anagrams together.

Function Signature:

List<List<String>> groupAnagrams(String[] strs)

Parameters:

  • strs: An array of strings representing the list of words.

Returns: A list of lists of strings, where each sublist contains words that are anagrams of each other.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer n, the number of strings.

  • The second line contains n space-separated strings, representing the elements of the array strs.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= strs.length <= 10^4

  • 0 <= strs[i].length <= 100

  • strs[i] consists of lowercase English letters.

Ravi and Priya are solving a puzzle where they need to find two numbers in an array that add up to a specific target. Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return the indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order.

Function Description: Complete the function twoSum which should find the indices of the two numbers that add up to the target.

Function Signature:

int[] twoSum(int[] nums, int target)

Parameters:

  • nums: An array of integers.

  • target: An integer representing the target sum.

Returns: An array of two integers representing the indices of the two numbers that add up to the target.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer n, the number of elements in the array.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, representing the elements of the array nums.

  • The third line contains an integer target.

Constraints:

  • 2 <= nums.length <= 10^4

  • -10^9 <= nums[i] <= 10^9

  • -10^9 <= target <= 10^9

  • Only one valid answer exists.

Ravi and Priya are exploring number theory and have come across the concept of a "happy number." A happy number is defined by the following process: Starting with any positive integer, replace the number by the sum of the squares of its digits. Repeat the process until the number equals 1 (where it will stay), or it loops endlessly in a cycle that does not include 1. Those numbers for which this process ends in 1 are happy numbers.

Given a number n, write an algorithm to determine if n is a happy number. Return true if n is a happy number, and false if not.

Function Description: Complete the function isHappy which should determine if the given number is a happy number.

Function Signature:

boolean isHappy(int n)

Parameters:

  • n: An integer representing the number to be checked.

Returns: A boolean value indicating whether the number is a happy number.

Input Format:

  • The input consists of a single integer n.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 2^31 - 1

Ravi and Priya are working on a project that involves analyzing sequences of numbers. They need to determine if there are any duplicate numbers in a given array such that the two indices of the duplicate numbers are at most k positions apart.

Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return true if there are two distinct indices i and j in the array such that nums[i] == nums[j] and abs(i - j) <= k.

Function Description: Complete the function containsNearbyDuplicate which should determine if there are any duplicate numbers within k positions apart.

Function Signature:

boolean containsNearbyDuplicate(int[] nums, int k)

Parameters:

  • nums: An array of integers.

  • k: An integer representing the maximum distance between duplicate indices.

Returns: A boolean value indicating whether there are any duplicate numbers within k positions apart.

Input Format:

  • The first line contains an integer n, the number of elements in the array.

  • The second line contains n space-separated integers, representing the elements of the array nums.

  • The third line contains an integer k.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5

  • -10^9 <= nums[i] <= 10^9

  • 0 <= k <= 10^5

Ravi and Priya are organizing a sequence game. They have an unsorted array of integers and want to find the length of the longest consecutive elements sequence. The sequence must be consecutive, meaning each number follows the previous one without any gaps.

Ramu has two numbers (A) and (B) ((A < B)).

Ramu will perform some operations on (A).

In the (i)-th operation:

  • Ramu will add 1 to (A) if (i) is odd.

  • Ramu will add 2 to (A) if (i) is even.

  • Ramu can stop at any instant. Can Ramu make (A) equal to (B)?

Input Format:
The first line contains a single integer (T) — the number of test cases. Then the test cases follow.
The first and only line of each test case contains two space-separated integers (A) and (B).

Output Format:
For each test case, output "YES" if Ramu can make (A) and (B) equal, "NO" otherwise.

Karthik wants to become fit, so he decided to walk to the office and return home by walking. Karthik's office is X km away from his home, and his office is open 5 days a week. Write a Java program that:

  1. Accepts the number of test cases N.

  2. For each test case, accepts an integer X, representing the distance in km between Karthik's home and office.

  3. Calculates the total distance Karthik travels through office trips in a week.

  4. Prints the calculated distance for each test case.

Note: Karthik makes a round trip (to office and back home) each working day.

Write a Java program that:

  1. Accepts an integer N, representing the number of sets (triples) of numbers.

  2. For each set, accepts three space-separated integers.

  3. Finds the second-maximum number among the three for each set.

  4. Prints the second-maximum number for each set on a new line.

Rahul wants to buy chocolates for his friend Priya. He has X number of 5 rupee coins and Y number of 10 rupee coins in his piggy bank. Rahul goes to a shop where each chocolate costs Z rupees. He wants to know how many chocolates he can buy for Priya with his money.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many times Rahul wants to try buying chocolates (N).

  2. For each try, you'll get three numbers:

    • X: How many 5 rupee coins Rahul has

    • Y: How many 10 rupee coins Rahul has

    • Z: How much one chocolate costs

  3. Your job is to find out how many chocolates Rahul can buy each time.

  4. Tell Rahul the number of chocolates he can buy for each try.

Ravi is learning about division in his math class. He wants to practice finding the leftover (remainder) when one number is divided by another. He needs your help to check his answers.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many division problems Ravi wants to try (N).

  2. For each problem, you'll get two numbers:

    • A: The big number Ravi wants to divide

    • B: The number Ravi is dividing by

  3. Your job is to find the leftover (remainder) for each division problem.

  4. Tell Ravi the leftover for each problem on a new line.

Ravi works at a candy store. The store has 100 chocolates. Ravi's boss gives him a daily goal to sell X chocolates. Ravi gets 1 rupee for each chocolate he sells up to his goal. If Ravi sells more than his goal, he gets 2 rupees for each extra chocolate. Ravi wants to know how much money he made in a day.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many days Ravi wants to calculate his earnings (N).

  2. For each day, you'll get two numbers:

    • X: Ravi's daily goal (how many chocolates he should sell)

    • Y: How many chocolates Ravi actually sold

  3. Your job is to find out how much money Ravi made that day.

  4. Tell Ravi his earnings for each day on a new line.

Riya is learning about different types of triangles in her math class. Her teacher told her about a special type of triangle called a scalene triangle. A scalene triangle has all three sides of different lengths. Riya wants to practice identifying scalene triangles and needs your help.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many triangles Riya wants to check (N).

  2. For each triangle, you'll get three numbers:

    • A: The length of the first side

    • B: The length of the second side

    • C: The length of the third side

  3. Your job is to tell if the triangle is scalene (all sides have different lengths) or not.

  4. Tell Riya "YES" if the triangle is scalene, and "NO" if it's not.

Aarav is learning about numbers. His teacher gave him a fun task: to add up all the digits in a big number. For example, if the number is 123, Aarav needs to add 1 + 2 + 3 = 6. Aarav wants to practice this with many numbers and needs your help to check his answers.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many numbers Aarav wants to practice with (N).

  2. For each practice, you'll get one big number.

  3. Your job is to add up all the digits in that number.

  4. Tell Aarav the sum of digits for each number on a new line.

Alice, Bob, and Charlie are friends who like different types of numbers. Alice likes numbers that are even (can be divided by 2) and can be divided by 7. Bob likes numbers that are odd (can't be divided by 2) and can be divided by 9. They find a number and want to know who should take it home.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many numbers the friends want to check (N).

  2. For each number, you need to figure out who takes it home:

    • If Alice likes the number, she takes it.

    • If Bob likes the number, he takes it.

    • If neither Alice nor Bob likes the number, Charlie takes it.

  3. Tell who takes each number home.

Ravi took tests in three subjects. He needs to make sure his grades are good enough to pass. Ravi will fail if the average (middle number) of any two subjects is less than 35. Ravi wants to know if he will pass or fail.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many times Ravi wants to check his grades (N).

  2. For each check, you'll get three numbers:

    • A: Ravi's score in the first subject

    • B: Ravi's score in the second subject

    • C: Ravi's score in the third subject

  3. Your job is to tell if Ravi will pass or fail.

  4. Tell Ravi "PASS" if he passes, or "FAIL" if he fails.

In Ravi's town, a valid phone number has 5 digits and doesn't start with 0. For example, 98765 and 10000 are valid, but 04123 and 9231 are not. Ravi bought some things at a store. He wants to know if his total bill looks like a valid phone number.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many times Ravi went shopping (N).

  2. For each shopping trip, you'll get two numbers:

    • N: How many things Ravi bought

    • X: How much each thing costs

  3. Your job is to check if the total bill (N * X) is a valid phone number.

  4. Tell Ravi "YES" if it's a valid phone number, or "NO" if it's not.

Ravi's teacher gave him a tricky task. Ravi needs to make a special string using only 0s and 1s. The string should be N digits long. The rule is: for any two numbers next to each other in the string, at least one of them must be 1. Ravi wants to use as few 1s as possible.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many puzzles Ravi needs to solve (T).

  2. For each puzzle, you'll get one number N, which is how long the string should be.

  3. Your job is to figure out the smallest number of 1s Ravi needs to use to make the string follow the rule.

  4. Tell Ravi the smallest number of 1s for each puzzle.

Ravi's teacher gave him three numbers: A, B, and C. Ravi needs to check if he can pick any two of these numbers that, when multiplied together, give a negative result.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many times Ravi will try this challenge (T).

  2. For each try, you'll get three numbers: A, B, and C.

  3. Your job is to check if Ravi can pick two numbers that multiply to give a negative answer.

  4. Tell Ravi "YES" if he can find two such numbers, or "NO" if he can't.

Ravi is learning about number patterns. He has two numbers, A and C, where A is not bigger than C. He wants to know if there's a number B that fits perfectly between A and C. The numbers A, B, and C should be evenly spaced, like steps on a ladder.

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many times Ravi wants to try this (N).

  2. For each try, you'll get two numbers:

    • A: The first number

    • C: The last number

  3. Your job is to find if there's a number B that fits evenly between A and C.

  4. If you find B, tell Ravi what B is. If there's no such B, tell Ravi -1.

Ravi is learning about special numbers in math class. His teacher gave him two numbers, A and B, and asked him to find two important things:

  1. The biggest number that can divide both A and B without leaving any remainder (this is called GCD).

  2. The smallest number that both A and B can divide without leaving any remainder (this is called LCM).

What You Need to Do:

  1. First, you'll be told how many times Ravi will solve this puzzle (T).

  2. For each puzzle, you'll get two numbers: A and B.

  3. Your job is to find the GCD and LCM of A and B.

  4. Tell Ravi the GCD and LCM for each puzzle, separated by a space, on a new line.

Alice has a big number N. She wants to know how many ways she can split this number into two smaller positive numbers. The order of the two numbers matters, so 1+2 and 2+1 are counted as different ways.

What You Need to Do:

  1. You'll get one number N from Alice.

  2. Your job is to find out in how many ways Alice can split N into two positive numbers that add up to N.

  3. Tell Alice how many ways there are.

Remember:

  • We only use whole numbers bigger than zero.

  • The order matters, so 1+2 and 2+1 are different ways.

Khan has two numbers (A) and (B).

In one operation, Khan can choose either (A) or (B) and multiply it by 2.

Determine whether he can make both (A) and (B) equal after any number (possibly, zero) of moves.

Input Format:
The first line of input will contain a single integer (T), denoting the number of test cases.
Each test case consists of two space-separated integers (A) and (B).

Output Format:
For each test case, output "YES" if Chef can make both numbers equal, "NO" otherwise.

You are given an integer (N). Determine if it is possible to represent (N) as the sum of several (possibly zero) 2's and several (possibly zero) 7's.

Formally, find if there exist two integers (X, Y) ((X, Y >= 0)) such that (2 * X + 7 * Y = N).

Input Format:

  • The first line of input will contain a single integer (T), denoting the number of test cases.

  • Each test case consists of a single line containing an integer (N).

Output Format:
For each test case, print on a new line "YES" if it is possible to represent (N) as the sum of several (possibly zero) 2's and several (possibly zero) 7's, and "NO" otherwise.

Santosh has a farm at Byteland. He has a very big family to look after. His life takes a sudden turn and he runs into a financial crisis. After giving all the money he has in his hand, he decides to sell his plots. The speciality of his land is that it is rectangular in nature. Santosh comes to know that he will get more money if he sells square-shaped plots. So keeping this in mind, he decides to divide his land into the minimum possible number of square plots, such that each plot has the same area, and the plots divide the land perfectly. He does this in order to get the maximum profit out of this.

Your task is to find the minimum number of square plots with the same area, that can be formed out of the rectangular land, such that they divide it perfectly.

Input Format:
The first line of the input contains (T), the number of test cases. Then (T) lines follow.
The first and only line of each test case contains two space-separated integers, (N) and (M), the length and the breadth of the land, respectively.

Output Format:
For each test case, print the minimum number of square plots with equal area, such that they divide the farmland perfectly, in a new line.

Virat and Rohit are playing a game with a number (X). In one turn, they can multiply (X) by 2. The goal of the game is to make (X) divisible by 10.

Help Virat and Rohit find the smallest number of turns necessary to win the game (it may be possible to win in zero turns) or determine that it is impossible.

Input Format:
The first line of the input contains a single integer (T) denoting the number of test cases. The description of (T) test cases follows.
The first and only line of each test case contains a single integer denoting the initial value of (X).

Output Format:
For each test case, print a single line containing one integer — the minimum required number of turns or -1 if there is no way to win the game.

Yesterday, puppy Tuzik learned a magically efficient method to find the sum of the integers from 1 to (N). He denotes it as sum(N). But today, as a true explorer, he defined his own new function: sum(D, N), which means the operation sum applied (D) times: the first time to (N), and each subsequent time to the result of the previous operation.

For example, if (D = 2) and (N = 3), then sum(2, 3) equals to sum(sum(3)) = sum(1 + 2 + 3) = sum(6) = 21.

Tuzik wants to calculate some values of the sum(D, N) function. Will you help him with that?

Input Format:
The first line contains a single integer (T), the number of test cases. Each test case is described by a single line containing two integers (D) and (N).

Output Format:
For each test case, output one integer on a separate line.

Raina likes the number 3 a lot.

He has two non-negative integers (A) and (B).
In one operation, Raina can do either of the following:

  1. (A := |A - B|) (change (A) to (|A - B|))

  2. (B := |A - B|) (change (B) to (|A - B|))

Note that (|X|) denotes the absolute value of (X). For example (|-7| = 7) and (|4| = 4).

Find the minimum number of operations after which at least one integer out of (A) and (B) becomes divisible by 3.

Input Format:
The first line of input contains a single integer (T), denoting the number of test cases. The description of (T) test cases follows.
The only line of each test case contains two integers (A) and (B).

Output Format:
For each test case, output in a single line the minimum number of operations after which at least one integer out of (A) and (B) becomes divisible by 3.

Return 0 if either A or B is already a multiple of 3

Return 1 if |A-B| is a multiple of 3

Return 2 If neither A nor B can be made a multiple of 3 in one move

You have (N) balls and (K) boxes. You want to divide the (N) balls into (K) boxes such that:

  1. Each box contains (>= 1) balls.

  2. No two boxes contain the same number of balls.

Determine if it is possible to do so.

Input Format:
The first line contains a single integer (T) — the number of test cases. Then the test cases follow.
The first and only line of each test case contains two space-separated integers (N) and (K) — the number of balls and the number of boxes respectively.

Output Format:
For each test case, output "YES" if it is possible to divide the (N) balls into (K) boxes such that the conditions are satisfied. Otherwise, output "NO".

In a bustling corporate office in Bengaluru, multiple teams need to conduct meetings, but there is only one meeting room available. The meeting room can host only one meeting at a time. Each meeting has a start and an end time, and the meetings cannot overlap.

You are given the start and end times of n meetings in the form of two arrays: start and end. The i-th element in the start array represents the start time of the i-th meeting, and the i-th element in the end array represents the end time of the i-th meeting. Your task is to determine the maximum number of meetings that can be accommodated in the meeting room without overlapping.

Note: The start time of one chosen meeting cannot be equal to the end time of another chosen meeting.

Write a function to determine the maximum number of non-overlapping meetings that can be scheduled.

Function Description:

Complete the function maxMeetings with the following parameters:

  • int[] start: an array representing the start times of the meetings.

  • int[] end: an array representing the end times of the meetings.

Returns:

  • int: the maximum number of meetings that can be held.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 10^5

  • 0 ≤ start[i] < end[i] ≤ 10^6

In a bustling market area of Varanasi, the local government is trying to count sub-segments of a specific path where there are a certain number of odd-numbered street lamps. Given an array nums representing the types of street lamps along a linear path, where each element represents the street lamp number, you are tasked with finding subarrays with exactly k odd-numbered street lamps.

The street lamp numbers in nums can be both even and odd, and you need to find how many nice subarrays have exactly k odd numbers.

For example, if we have the array [1, 1, 2, 1, 1] and k = 3, there are 2 subarrays with 3 odd numbers ([1, 1, 2, 1] and [1, 2, 1, 1]).

Function Description:
Complete the function countNiceSubarrays as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • int[] nums: An array of integers representing the street lamp numbers.

    • int k: The target number of odd-numbered street lamps.

  • Returns:

    • int: The number of nice subarrays with exactly k odd numbers.

The function should look like this:

public int countNiceSubarrays(int[] nums, int k)

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ nums.length ≤ 50000

  • 1 ≤ nums[i] ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ k ≤ nums.length

In the bustling city of Bengaluru, a group of students is trying to divide a pile of study material into smaller sections to make their studying more manageable. They want to split the study material into different subarrays such that each student can handle one subarray. However, they want to ensure that the workload is minimized across students.

Given an array nums representing the amount of study material (in pages) and an integer k representing the number of students, divide nums into k non-empty subarrays such that the largest sum of any subarray is minimized.

Your task is to return the minimized largest sum of the split.

A subarray is a contiguous part of the array.

Function Description:

Complete the function splitArray as described below:

public static int splitArray(int[] nums, int k)
Parameters:

  • int[] nums: An array of integers representing the pages in each material section.

  • int k: The number of students.

Returns:

  • int: The minimized largest sum among all subarrays.

Task:

Write a function that splits the array nums into k parts such that the largest sum among these parts is minimized.

Imagine you are conducting a survey where you collect sequences of different items chosen by people, and your task is to determine how many times people chose exactly k distinct items in a given sequence. Each person’s choices are represented as an array, nums, where each element is a distinct item. Your task is to count how many subarrays contain exactly k different integers.

For example, given the array [1, 2, 1, 2, 3] and k = 2, there are 7 subarrays that contain exactly 2 different items.

Function Description:
Complete the function subarraysWithKDistinct as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • int[] nums: An array of integers representing people's choices.

    • int k: The number of distinct items to look for.

  • Returns:

    • int: The number of subarrays that contain exactly k distinct integers.

The function should look like this:

public int subarraysWithKDistinct(int[] nums, int k)

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ nums.length ≤ 2 * 10^4

  • 1 ≤ nums[i], k ≤ nums.length

You are given two strings, s and t, with lengths m and n respectively. Your task is to find the minimum window substring in s that contains all the characters of t (including duplicates). The answer should be the shortest possible substring that has all the characters of t.

If such a substring does not exist, return an empty string "".

For example, consider the string s = "ADOBECODEBANC" and t = "ABC". The shortest substring in s that contains all characters from t is "BANC". This problem can be visualized as finding a window within the larger string s that completely captures every character from t with minimum length.

Function Description: Complete the function minWindow as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • String s: The main string where we need to find the substring.

    • String t: The target string containing the characters to be included.

  • Returns:

    • String: The minimum window substring containing all characters of t.

The function signature should look like this:

public String minWindow(String s, String t)

Constraints:

  • m == s.length

  • n == t.length

  • 1 ≤ m, n ≤ 10^5

  • s and t consist of uppercase and lowercase English letters.

There are n children standing in a line. Each child is assigned a rating value given in the integer array ratings.

You need to distribute candies to these children subject to the following requirements:

  • Each child must have at least one candy.

  • Children with a higher rating get more candies than their neighbors.

Your task is to determine the minimum number of candies needed to distribute to all the children such that the above conditions are met.

Example: Consider the ratings array [1, 0, 2]. You can distribute candies such that the first, second, and third children get 2, 1, and 2 candies, respectively, for a total of 5 candies.

Function Description:

Complete the function minCandies with the following parameter:

  • int[] ratings: an array of integers representing the rating values of each child.

Returns:

  • int: the minimum number of candies needed.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 2 * 10^4

  • 0 ≤ ratings[i] ≤ 2 * 10^4

In the vibrant streets of Kolkata, a colorful banner is being designed, consisting of only three colors represented by the letters a, b, and c. You are tasked with counting how many sub-banners (substrings) have at least one occurrence of all three colors.

The string s represents the banner sequence and consists of only the letters a, b, and c. Your goal is to determine how many substrings contain all three characters (a, b, and c) at least once.

For example, if you have a banner represented by "abcabc", there are 10 substrings that contain all three colors at least once.

Function Description:
Complete the function countSubstringsWithAllThreeChars as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • String s: A string consisting of the characters a, b, and c.

  • Returns:

    • int: The number of substrings that contain at least one occurrence of a, b, and c.

The function should look like this:

public int countSubstringsWithAllThreeChars(String s)

Constraints:

  • 3 ≤ s.length ≤ 5 * 10^4

  • s only consists of characters a, b, or c.

In a casino, there are several cards arranged in a row, each card having a certain number of points. The casino offers a game where you can pick cards from either the beginning or the end of the row to maximize your points.

You are given an array, cardPoints, where each element represents the number of points associated with a card. You must take exactly k cards, choosing from either end. Your goal is to maximize the total score.

For instance, if you have cards with points [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1] and you need to take k = 3 cards, the best approach is to take cards from the right end, which yields a maximum score of 1 + 6 + 5 = 12.

Function Description:
Complete the function maxScore as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • int[] cardPoints: An array of integers representing points associated with each card.

    • int k: The number of cards you must take.

  • Returns:

    • int: The maximum score you can achieve by selecting k cards from either end of the array.

The function should look like this:

public int maxScore(int[] cardPoints, int k)

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ cardPoints.length ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ cardPoints[i] ≤ 10^4

  • 1 ≤ k ≤ cardPoints.length

In a crowded shopping mall, you are trying to find out the longest consecutive string of shops where there are at most k different shop types. The string s represents the sequence of shops in the mall, and each character in the string represents a different shop type.

You are tasked with finding the length of the longest substring that contains at most k distinct shop types. This will help in finding a shopping route with the least variety of shops for maximum time savings.

For example, given the string "eceba" and k = 2, the answer would be the substring "ece" with a length of 3.

Function Description:
Complete the function longestSubstringWithKDistinctChars as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • String s: A string representing different types of shops.

    • int k: The maximum number of distinct shop types allowed.

  • Returns:

    • int: The length of the longest substring containing at most k distinct characters.

The function should look like this:

public int longestSubstringWithKDistinctChars(String s, int k)

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ s.length ≤ 5 * 10^4

  • 0 ≤ k ≤ 50

You are given two arrays, val[] and wt[], representing the values and weights of items, respectively, and an integer capacity that represents the maximum weight a knapsack can carry. Your task is to determine the maximum total value that can be achieved by putting items in the knapsack. You are allowed to take fractions of items if necessary.

The items can be broken into parts to fit into the knapsack, and your goal is to maximize the total value that the knapsack holds.

Return the maximum value as a double, rounded to 6 decimal places.

For instance, if you are given items with values [60, 100, 120] and weights [10, 20, 30], with a capacity of 50, you should maximize the value by taking complete items and fractions as needed.

Function Description: Complete the function fractionalKnapsack as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • int[] val: An array of integers representing the values of items.

    • int[] wt: An array of integers representing the weights of items.

    • int capacity: The total weight capacity of the knapsack.

  • Returns:

    • double: The maximum value that can be obtained by filling the knapsack.

The function should look like this:

public double fractionalKnapsack(int[] val, int[] wt, int capacity)

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ val.length = wt.length ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ capacity ≤ 10^9

  • 1 ≤ val[i], wt[i] ≤ 10^4

You are given an array of coins coins[] of size N and a target value sum. Each coins[i] represents a coin with a specific denomination, and you have an infinite supply of each coin. Your task is to determine the minimum number of coins required to make up the target value sum. If it is not possible to make the given sum, return -1.

For example, if you are given the coins {25, 10, 5} and need to make 30, the minimum number of coins needed would be 2 (25 and 5).

The solution should aim to minimize the number of coins used to make the sum.

Function Description: Complete the function coinChange as follows:

  • Parameters:

    • int[] coins: An array of integers representing different coin denominations.

    • int sum: The target sum value.

  • Returns:

    • int: The minimum number of coins needed to achieve the target sum, or -1 if it is not possible.

The function should look like this:

public int coinChange(int[] coins, int sum)

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ coins.length ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ sum ≤ 10^9

  • 1 ≤ coins[i] ≤ 10^4

You are playing a jump game where you need to jump from the first position in an array to the last position. You are initially positioned at the array's first index, and each element in the array represents the maximum jump length you can make from that position.

Your task is to determine if it is possible to reach the last index starting from the first index.

Write a function that returns true if you can reach the last index, or false otherwise.

Example: Consider the array nums = [2, 3, 1, 1, 4]. You can jump 1 step from index 0 to 1, then jump 3 steps to the last index, meaning it is possible to reach the end.

Function Description:

Complete the function canJump with the following parameters:

  • int[] nums: an array representing the maximum jump lengths at each position.

Returns:

  • boolean: true if you can reach the last index, otherwise false.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ nums.length ≤ 10^4

  • 0 ≤ nums[i] ≤ 10^5

You are given a 0-indexed array of integers nums of length n. You are initially positioned at nums[0], and each element in the array represents the maximum length of a forward jump you can make from that position.

Your task is to determine the minimum number of jumps required to reach the last index of the array starting from the first index.

Write a function that returns the minimum number of jumps to reach the last index.

The test cases are guaranteed such that you can always reach nums[n - 1] from nums[0].

Example: Consider the array nums = [2, 3, 1, 1, 4]. The minimum number of jumps to reach the last index is 2. Jump 1 step from index 0 to 1, then jump 3 steps to the last index.

Function Description:

Complete the function minJumps with the following parameters:

  • int[] nums: an array representing the maximum jump lengths at each position.

Returns:

  • int: the minimum number of jumps required to reach the last index.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ nums.length ≤ 10^4

  • 0 ≤ nums[i] ≤ 1000

  • It is guaranteed that you can reach the last index from the first index.

A railway station has multiple trains arriving and departing throughout the day. Given the arrival and departure times of all trains that reach the station, you need to find the minimum number of platforms required so that no train has to wait.

Consider that all trains arrive on the same day and leave on the same day. The arrival time and departure time can never be the same for a train, but different trains may have the same arrival or departure times. At any given time, a platform cannot be shared by both a departing train and an arriving train.

Write a function to determine the minimum number of platforms required at the railway station.

Note: Time intervals are given in 24-hour format (HHMM), where the first two characters represent hours (00 to 23), and the last two characters represent minutes (00 to 59).

Function Description:

Complete the function findPlatforms with the following parameters:

  • int[] arr: an array of integers representing the arrival times of trains in HHMM format.

  • int[] dep: an array of integers representing the departure times of trains in HHMM format.

Returns:

  • int: the minimum number of platforms required.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ number of trains ≤ 50,000

  • 0000 ≤ arr[i] ≤ dep[i] ≤ 2359

You are given an array, jobs[], where each job has a jobId, deadline, and profit associated with it. Each job takes 1 unit of time to complete, and only one job can be scheduled at a time. You earn the profit associated with a job if and only if it is completed by its deadline.

Find the maximum number of jobs that can be done and the maximum profit that can be earned.

Write a function that returns the number of jobs completed and the maximum profit.

Note: The jobs[] array is given in the form (jobId, deadline, profit) associated with each job. The deadline of the job is the time by which the job must be completed to earn the profit.

Function Description:

Complete the function jobSequencing with the following parameter:

  • Job[] jobs: an array of Job objects, where each object contains jobId, deadline, and profit.

Returns:

  • int[]: an array of size 2, where the first element represents the number of jobs done, and the second element represents the maximum profit earned.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ jobs.size ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ deadline, jobId ≤ jobs.size

  • 1 ≤ profit ≤ 500

Geek is a software engineer. He is assigned the task of calculating the average waiting time of all processes by following the shortest job first (SJF) policy.

The shortest job first (SJF) or shortest job next is a scheduling policy that selects the waiting process with the smallest execution time to execute next.

You are given an array of integers bt of size n. The array bt represents the burst time of each process. Your task is to calculate the average waiting time of all processes and return the nearest integer which is smaller or equal to the calculated average waiting time.

Note: Consider all processes are available at time 0.

Function Description:

Complete the function averageWaitingTime with the following parameter:

  • int[] bt: an array representing the burst time of each process.

Returns:

  • int: the average waiting time of all processes rounded down to the nearest integer.

Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 10^5

  • 1 ≤ bt[i] ≤ 10^5

Ravi is working as a system administrator in an IT firm in Hyderabad. One of his tasks is to optimize the memory performance of their servers. As part of memory management, the server uses a paging technique to manage memory allocations, and Ravi needs to implement the Least Recently Used (LRU) page replacement algorithm to make sure that pages that are no longer actively used are replaced effectively.

The LRU algorithm is widely used in operating systems for deciding which pages to remove from memory whenever a new page needs to be loaded. A page fault occurs if the page requested by the process is not present in memory, and the operating system must bring it into memory by replacing an existing page. The task is to find out how many page faults occur using this LRU policy, given a sequence of pages requested by the system.

Scenario Example: Imagine Ravi has a sequence of page requests – {5, 0, 1, 3, 2, 4, 1, 0, 5} – and the memory can only hold 4 pages at a time. Initially, when pages are being requested, they are loaded into empty slots in the memory. If a page request comes and it is not in memory (a "page fault"), the Least Recently Used page is removed from memory to make space for the new page. Ravi needs your help to find out how many page faults will occur.

Explain with Example: Consider the input: Number of pages N = 9, Capacity of memory C = 4, and the pages to be loaded are {5, 0, 1, 3, 2, 4, 1, 0, 5}.

  • Initially, the memory slots are empty. When Ravi starts loading pages, he first adds 5, 0, 1, and 3, and all pages are loaded without any page replacement as memory has enough capacity.

  • Next, page 2 is required, which causes a page fault as the memory is full and page 5 needs to be removed since it was least recently used.

  • Continuing in this way, you must find how many times a page fault occurs.

Function Description:

  • Function Name: pageFaults

  • Parameters:

    • int N: Number of pages to load (1 <= N <= 1000).

    • int C: Capacity of the memory, or number of pages the memory can hold (1 <= C <= 1000).

    • int[] pages: An array of integers representing page requests (each value 0 <= pages[i] <= 100).

  • Returns: An integer value representing the total number of page faults.

  • Detailed Task: Implement the function to take the given list of page requests, the capacity, and compute the total number of page faults using the LRU page replacement policy. Ensure the solution is efficient and well-structured.

  1. Constraints:

  • The number of pages N is between 1 and 1000.

  • Capacity of memory C is between 1 and 1000.

  • Pages are integers between 0 and 100.

Imagine Asha runs a successful event organizing company in Bengaluru. She manages a calendar of non-overlapping events, where each event has a starting and ending time, and they are all sorted in chronological order. One day, a new event request comes in, and Asha needs to add this new event to the existing schedule while making sure that none of the events overlap. If the new event overlaps with existing events, Asha will need to merge those events accordingly.

For example, if Asha has events scheduled as [[1,3], [6,9]], and a new event [2,5] arrives, she needs to combine the overlapping events to end up with [[1,5], [6,9]]. Your task is to help Asha manage her event schedule by inserting new events into an existing schedule and merging overlapping ones if necessary.

Explain with Example:

Consider Asha has the existing schedule as [[1,2], [3,5], [6,7], [8,10], [12,16]] and a new event [4,8] comes in. The event [4,8] overlaps with existing intervals [3,5], [6,7], and [8,10]. Therefore, we need to merge these events, resulting in the updated schedule: [[1,2], [3,10], [12,16]].

  1. Function Description:

  • Function Name: insertInterval

  • Parameters:

    • List<List<Integer>> intervals: A list of lists where each sublist contains two integers representing the start and end time of an interval. (0 <= intervals.length <= 10^4).

    • List<Integer> newInterval: A list of two integers representing the start and end time of the new interval.

  • Returns: A list of lists of integers representing the updated schedule after inserting the new interval and merging any overlapping intervals.

  • Detailed Task: Implement a function that takes a list of existing non-overlapping intervals sorted by starting time and inserts a new interval into the list, while ensuring that the final schedule is sorted and contains no overlapping intervals.

  1. Constraints:

  • The number of intervals is between 0 and 10^4.

  • The start and end values of each interval are between 0 and 10^5.

  • The list of intervals is sorted by the start time.

  • The new interval is a list containing two integers, where 0 <= start <= end <= 10^5.

In a city like Mumbai, several busy roads intersect and cause traffic congestion. Traffic police often decide to merge multiple lanes together to streamline the flow and avoid bottlenecks. Similarly, you are given an array of intervals that represent ranges, and your task is to merge overlapping intervals so that there is no congestion or overlap left.

Consider Ravi, a project manager who is trying to schedule meetings throughout the day. He has received a list of intervals representing booked meetings. Some meetings overlap, creating confusion in the schedule. Ravi has requested your help to merge all overlapping meetings into a new, non-overlapping list.

You need to write a function that takes an array of non-overlapping intervals, where intervals[i] = [start_i, end_i], and merge all overlapping intervals to create a new list of merged intervals. The goal is to return an array of non-overlapping intervals that represent the original schedule without conflicts.

For instance, if Ravi has scheduled meetings from [1, 3] and [2, 6], you can merge them into a single meeting [1, 6]. Your task is to ensure that the list of intervals is clear and non-overlapping after all necessary merges.

Explain with Example:

Consider the input intervals: [[1, 3], [2, 6], [8, 10], [15, 18]].

  • Initially, we have overlapping intervals [1, 3] and [2, 6], which can be merged into [1, 6].

  • Other intervals [8, 10] and [15, 18] do not overlap with any others, so they stay the same.

  • The final merged intervals are [[1, 6], [8, 10], [15, 18]].

  1. Function Description:

  • Function Name: mergeIntervals

  • Parameters:

    • int[][] intervals: An array of non-overlapping intervals, where each interval is represented by [start_i, end_i]. (1 ≤ intervals.length ≤ 10^4)

  • Returns: A new list of merged intervals that are sorted and non-overlapping.

  • Detailed Task: Write a function to merge all overlapping intervals and return the non-overlapping schedule. If an interval [i, j] overlaps with another interval [j, k], merge them into [i, k].

  1. Constraints:

  • 1 ≤ intervals.length ≤ 10^4

  • intervals[i].length == 2

  • 0 ≤ start_i ≤ end_i ≤ 10^4

Priya is a software engineer from Pune and recently, she has been given the task of processing some schedule data. She has an array of intervals, each representing a meeting start and end time. Imagine you are an astronaut tasked with observing and analyzing a row of asteroids moving through space. The asteroids are represented as an array of integers where the absolute value represents the size of each asteroid, and the sign indicates its direction. Positive numbers indicate an asteroid moving to the right, while negative numbers indicate an asteroid moving to the left. All asteroids move at the same speed.

The challenge is to determine the final state of the asteroids after all possible collisions. If two asteroids collide, the smaller one explodes. If they are of equal size, both explode. Asteroids moving in the same direction will never collide.

Write a function that determines the state of the asteroids after all collisions.

  • int[] asteroids: An array of integers representing the asteroids in a row.

Returns:

  • int[]: The array representing the state of the asteroids after all collisions.

Constraints:

  • 2 ≤ asteroids.length ≤ 10^4

  • -1000 ≤ asteroids[i] ≤ 1000

  • asteroids[i] != 0

You are a professional robber planning to rob houses along a street. Each house has a certain amount of money stashed, but the only constraint stopping you from robbing each of them is that adjacent houses have security systems connected, and they will automatically contact the police if two adjacent houses are broken into on the same night.

Your goal is to return the maximum amount of money you can rob tonight without alerting the police.

Given an integer array nums representing the amount of money of each house, write a function that returns the maximum amount of money you can rob without robbing two adjacent houses.

  • 0 ≤ nums[i] ≤ 400

The residents of the city of Jaipur are planning to establish a minimum transportation route for a newly developed district. Imagine this district is arranged in a grid pattern with m rows and n columns, and each cell in the grid represents a street block. Each block has a specific cost associated with passing through it. Your task is to help them determine the cheapest route from the top-left block to the bottom-right block.

The route can only move either down or to the right at any point in time, ensuring a smooth flow of traffic without any backtracking. Given a grid that represents the cost of traveling through each block, calculate the minimum possible sum for any path from the top-left to the bottom-right.

For example, consider a 3x3 grid where each cell is filled with the costs to pass through. To minimize costs, only choose to move down or right until reaching the destination.

The residents of Jaipur need your help to determine the most cost-effective route.

  • int[][] grid: A 2D array where each cell contains the cost to move through that specific block.

Returns:

  • int: The minimum sum of the path from the top-left to the bottom-right.

Constraints:

  • m == grid.length

  • n == grid[i].length

  • 1 <= m, n <= 200

  • 0 <= grid[i][j] <= 200

You are given an array of positive integers, arr, and a target value called sum. Your task is to determine whether there exists a subset of elements in the given array that adds up exactly to the value sum.

Consider that you are a mathematician in a village where you are given a collection of coins, each representing a specific value. You need to determine if it's possible to gather some of these coins to reach a specific target value that represents the cost of goods. This will help you and the village accountant to decide whether a purchase is feasible or not.

For example, if the available coins are [3, 34, 4, 12, 5, 2] and the required sum is 9, then you can select a subset of coins [4, 3, 2] that adds up to 9.

Complete the function isSubsetSum with the following parameters:

      • int sum: The target sum we want to determine if it's achievable with a subset of elements from the array.

    • Returns:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= arr.length <= 200

  • 1 <= arr[i] <= 200

  • 1 <= sum <= 4 * 10^4

You are given two strings, text1 and text2, and you need to determine the length of their longest common subsequence.

A subsequence of a string is a new string that is derived from the original string with some characters (possibly none) deleted without changing the relative order of the remaining characters.

For example, "ace" is a subsequence of "abcde".

A common subsequence of two strings is a subsequence that is present in both strings. The longest common subsequence is the one with the maximum length among all possible common subsequences.

If there is no common subsequence, return 0.

For example, given text1 = "abcde" and text2 = "ace", the longest common subsequence is "ace", and its length is 3.

Write a function to determine the length of the longest common subsequence.

Function Description: Complete the function int longestCommonSubsequence(String text1, String text2) that takes in:

  • String text1: A string containing lowercase English characters.

  • String text2: A string containing lowercase English characters.

Returns:

  • int: The length of the longest common subsequence.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= text1.length, text2.length <= 1000

  • text1 and text2 consist only of lowercase English characters.

You are given two strings, text1 and text2, and you need to determine the length of their longest common subsequence.

A subsequence of a string is a new string that is derived from the original string with some characters (possibly none) deleted without changing the relative order of the remaining characters.

A common subsequence of two strings is a subsequence that is present in both strings. The longest common subsequence is the one with the maximum length among all possible common subsequences.

You are given a string s and need to determine the length of the longest palindromic subsequence.

Varanasi's famous library is undertaking a special project to digitize its old manuscripts. These manuscripts contain words that need to be converted to new formats to match standardized vocabulary. Given the nature of language, you are allowed to perform the following operations to achieve the transformation:

  1. Insert a character: Adding a new character anywhere in the word.

  2. Delete a character: Removing any character from the word.

  3. Replace a character: Changing one character to another.

You are given two strings, word1 and word2. Your task is to determine the minimum number of operations required to transform word1 into word2 using the allowed operations.

For example:

  • If you are given word1 as "horse" and word2 as "ros", you can convert "horse" to "ros" in 3 steps:

    1. Replace 'h' with 'r' to get "rorse".

    2. Remove 'r' to get "rose".

    3. Remove 'e' to get "ros".

This is a common scenario faced when digitizing and standardizing manuscript vocabulary for consistency.

Complete the function minDistance as described below:

public static int minDistance(String word1, String word2)

Returns:

Your function should calculate the minimum number of operations needed to convert the given word1 to word2 using any combination of the three allowed operations (insert, delete, replace).

  • word1 and word2 consist of lowercase English letters only.

Imagine you are given a sequence of numbers representing the heights of buildings along a street in Bangalore. Your task is to find the length of the longest strictly increasing sequence of building heights.

For example:

A strictly increasing subsequence is a part of the array where each subsequent element is greater than the previous one. You need to find the longest such subsequence possible.

Suman is a software engineer working in Chennai, and she is working on optimizing her algorithms for text matching. While working on a recent task, she stumbled upon a problem where she needed to determine how many times a string a must be repeated for it to contain another string b as a substring. Suman decided to write a function to solve this problem efficiently.

You are given two strings a and b. Your task is to return the minimum number of times you should repeat string a so that string b becomes a substring of the repeated string a. If it is impossible for b to be a substring of the repeated version of a, return -1.

Notice: If a = "abc", repeating it 0 times gives "", repeating it 1 time gives "abc", and repeating it 2 times gives "abcabc".

For example:

  • If a = "abcd" and b = "cdabcdab", repeating a three times yields "abcdabcdabcd", where b is a substring of the repeated string a. Hence, the answer would be 3.

Complete the function repeatedStringMatch as described below:

  • String b: The target substring that must be contained in the repeated string.

Returns:

  • int: The minimum number of times a should be repeated so that b becomes a substring. Return -1 if it is not possible.

Task:

Write a function that calculates and returns the minimum number of repetitions required for b to be a substring of repeated a.

Constraints:

  • 1 <= a.length, b.length <= 104

  • a and b consist of lowercase English letters.

In the colorful garden of Ramesh's house in Bangalore, there are several flowers that bloom on different days. To make a bouquet, he needs to pick a specified number of adjacent flowers from the garden.

Lakshmi is organizing her warehouse in Delhi, and she wants to divide her inventory into different stacks. Each stack should not exceed a certain limit in weight. Given an array of inventory weights (nums), and a threshold value (threshold), she needs to determine the smallest possible divisor such that the sum of the division results is less than or equal to the threshold.

You are given an array of integers nums and an integer threshold.

  • You need to find the smallest divisor such that dividing each element of the array by this divisor (and rounding the result up to the nearest integer) results in a sum that is less than or equal to the threshold.

For each result of the division, round it up to the nearest integer greater than or equal to that element. (For example: 7 / 3 = 3 and 10 / 2 = 5).

Write a function that returns this smallest possible divisor.

A conveyor belt has packages that must be shipped from one port to another within days days. Each package on the conveyor belt has a weight represented by an integer array weights. In a library, there are a number of books arranged in a row. Each book has a different number of pages, and these books need to be distributed among a certain number of students. The objective is to minimize the maximum number of pages allocated to a student.

You are tasked with helping a painting company complete a large task. The company has been hired to paint n wooden boards, and they want to divide the workload between multiple painters to minimize the time taken to complete the entire job.

In a small tech town, Ramesh, an aspiring computer science student, is learning about binary numbers. He finds it fascinating how computers represent numbers using only 1s and 0s. In an environment without the traditional mathematical operators, Vikas is trying to create his own division program for two integers. He wants to determine the quotient when a dividend is divided by a divisor, without using multiplication, division, or mod operators.

Lakshmi is working on a project that involves analyzing sorted lists of positive integers. A number is considered missing if it is greater than 0 but does not appear in the given list.
